Domain-1.overview: Secure Infrastructure refers to the establishment of robust and resilient systems that safeguard digital assets and data against unauthorised access, breaches, and cyber threats. It involves implementing a combination of hardware, software, policies, and procedures designed to protect networks, servers, applications, and other critical components from vulnerabilities and attacks. By prioritizing security measures such as encryption, access controls, and regular audits, organizations can mitigate risks and ensure the integrity and confidentiality of their infrastructure.
Domain-1.title: Secure Infrastructure
Domain-1.1-summary: Configuration management is the systematic process of managing and controlling changes to a systems configuration ensuring consistently, reliability and traceability throughout its lifecycle
Domain-1.1-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Configuration Management Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Centralize Configuration: Use a dedicated configuration management tool.
  • Define Standards: Document approved configurations and baselines.
  • Inventory Assets: Track all hardware and software.
  • Establish Baselines: Define known good configurations.
  • Control Changes: Implement a formal change management process.
  • Secure Access: Control access to configuration management tools.
  • Train Personnel: Educate on standards and tools.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Automate Configuration: Use infrastructure-as-code (IaC).
  • Version Control: Track configuration changes.
  • Immutable Infrastructure (Where Possible): Replace instead of modifying.
  • Desired State Configuration: Enforce intended configurations.
  • Continuous Monitoring: Detect configuration drift.
  • Automated Remediation: Automatically correct deviations.
  • Secure Templates: Use hardened configuration templates.
  • Configuration Validation: Test configurations before deployment.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals.
  • Regular Audits: Verify configuration compliance.
  • Regular Reviews: Update standards and processes.
  • Measure Compliance: Track adherence to standards.
  • Foster Consistency: Promote standardized configurations.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Cloud Configurations: Manage cloud resources as code.
  • Containerization: Define and manage container configurations.
  • Network Configuration: Automate network device configurations.
  • Security Hardening: Implement security best practices in configurations.
Domain-1.2-summary: Infrastructure segmentation is the practice of dividing a network's resources and services into separate segments or zones to enhance security, improve performance, and facilitate easier management. This approach helps isolate critical assets, limit the spread of potential security breaches, and ensure that only authorised users have access to sensitive information. By implementing infrastructure segmentation, organizations can effectively enforce security policies, reduce the risk of unauthorised access, and support compliance efforts, all while maintaining operational efficiency across their IT environments.
Domain-1.2-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Infrastructure Network Segmentation Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define Zones: Identify distinct security zones based on risk.
  • Establish Policy: Document segmentation rules and rationale.
  • Inventory Assets: Understand network components and their purpose.
  • Risk Assessment: Prioritize segmentation based on potential impact.
  • Least Privilege (Network): Allow only necessary network communication.
  • Document Architecture: Maintain clear network segmentation diagrams.
  • Train Personnel: Educate on segmentation policies and tools.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Implement Firewalls: Use firewalls to enforce zone boundaries.
  • VLANs/Subnets: Utilize logical network separation.
  • Microsegmentation: Implement granular control at workload level.
  • Access Control Lists (ACLs): Define specific traffic rules.
  • Software-Defined Networking (SDN): Leverage for dynamic segmentation.
  • Intrusion Detection/Prevention (IDS/IPS): Monitor traffic between segments.
  • Secure Routing: Implement secure routing protocols.
  • Regular Testing: Validate segmentation effectiveness.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals.
  • Regular Audits: Verify segmentation compliance.
  • Regular Reviews: Update segmentation policies and architecture.
  • Measure Effectiveness: Track incidents related to segmentation.
  • Adopt Zero Trust Principles: Assume no implicit trust between segments.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Cloud Segmentation: Utilize cloud-native network security controls.
  • Container Networking: Secure communication between containers.
  • OT/ICS Segmentation: Isolate operational technology networks.
  • Remote Access: Securely segment remote user connections.
Domain-1.3-summary: Logging and monitoring encompass the collection and analysis of system and application logs to identify, diagnose, and respond to potential issues, ensuring operational health and security. Logging and monitoring aid in detecting anomalies, optimizing performance, and maintaining compliance within IT environments.
Domain-1.3-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Logging & Monitoring Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define Scope: Identify critical systems and data to log.
  • Establish Policy: Document logging standards and retention.
  • Centralize Logging: Aggregate logs in a secure platform.
  • Standardize Format: Ensure consistent log structure.
  • Time Synchronization: Implement NTP for accurate timestamps.
  • Secure Logging Infrastructure: Protect log data integrity and confidentiality.
  • Train Personnel: Educate on logging policies and tools.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Comprehensive Logging: Capture relevant events (security, system, application).
  • Real-time Monitoring: Implement tools for live data analysis.
  • Alerting & Notifications: Configure alerts for critical events.
  • Thresholding & Baselines: Establish normal behavior and deviations.
  • Correlation & Analysis: Use tools to connect related events.
  • Log Retention: Store logs for appropriate periods.
  • Log Analysis Tools (SIEM): Implement a Security Information and Event Management system.
  • Automated Response: Trigger actions based on alerts.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals.
  • Regular Audits: Verify logging and monitoring effectiveness.
  • Regular Reviews: Update logging policies and monitoring rules.
  • Measure Effectiveness: Track detection rates and response times.
  • Tune Alerting: Minimize false positives and negatives.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Cloud Logging: Utilize cloud-native logging services.
  • Container Logging: Aggregate logs from containerized applications.
  • Network Monitoring: Capture and analyze network traffic logs.
  • Application Performance Monitoring (APM): Integrate with application logs.
Domain-1.4-summary: Automated policy enforcement enables the continuous application and compliance verification of defined security policies across an IT environment, ensuring configurations and operations adhere to established standards. This mechanism streamlines security management, reduces human error, and ensures a consistent security posture through automation.
Domain-1.4-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Automated Policy Enforcement Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define Clear Policies: Document policies in a machine-readable format.
  • Identify Enforceable Policies: Determine which policies can be automated.
  • Centralize Policy Management: Use a dedicated policy management platform.
  • Standardize Policy Language: Adopt a consistent language for defining rules.
  • Map Policies to Controls: Link policies to technical enforcement mechanisms.
  • Secure Policy Storage: Protect policy definitions from unauthorized modification.
  • Train Personnel: Educate on policy automation and tools.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Infrastructure-as-Code (IaC): Embed policies in infrastructure definitions.
  • Configuration Management Tools: Automate configuration enforcement.
  • Cloud Policy Engines: Utilize cloud-native policy enforcement services.
  • Security Automation Tools: Implement automated security controls.
  • Continuous Compliance Checks: Regularly verify policy adherence.
  • Automated Remediation: Automatically correct policy violations.
  • Policy Testing & Validation: Test automated policies before deployment.
  • Integration with CI/CD: Enforce policies early in the development lifecycle.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for policy automation.
  • Regular Audits: Verify the effectiveness of automated enforcement.
  • Regular Reviews: Update automated policies based on changes.
  • Measure Compliance: Track the level of automated policy adherence.
  • Iterative Implementation: Gradually automate policy enforcement.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Identity and Access Management (IAM): Automate role-based access controls.
  • Network Security Policies: Automate firewall rules and network segmentation.
  • Endpoint Security Policies: Automate configuration and compliance on endpoints.
  • Data Governance Policies: Automate data security and compliance rules.
Domain-1.5-summary: Secrets management involves the secure handling, storage, and access control of sensitive information such as passwords, keys, certificates and tokens to prevent unauthorised access and breaches. It ensures that secrets are encrypted, access is strictly controlled, and usage is audited, bolstering an organization's security framework.
Domain-1.5-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Secrets Management Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Centralize Secrets: Use a dedicated secrets management platform.
  • Define Clear Policy: Document usage, rotation, access, and responsibilities.
  • Inventory Secrets: Find all existing secrets.
  • Classify Sensitivity: Categorize secrets by impact.
  • Least Privilege: Grant minimal necessary access.
  • Secure Platform Access: Use MFA and RBAC for the secrets tool.
  • Educate Employees: Train on policy and tool usage.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Automate Rotation: Regularly rotate secrets programmatically.
  • Secure Generation: Use strong, random secret generation.
  • Encrypt Secrets: Encrypt at rest and in transit.
  • Secure Retrieval: Applications retrieve programmatically (no hardcoding).
  • Use Dynamic Secrets (Where Possible): Short-lived, on-demand secrets.
  • Integrate with Infrastructure: Connect to CI/CD, cloud, etc.
  • Robust Auditing: Log all access and changes.
  • Monitor for Spillage: Detect accidental secret exposure.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals.
  • Regular Policy Review: Update policies and procedures.
  • Regular Security Assessments: Include secrets management in testing.
  • Measure Maturity: Track progress with key metrics.
  • Foster Security Culture: Make secrets security a shared responsibility.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Cloud Native: Use cloud secrets services securely.
  • DevOps Integration: Seamlessly integrate into workflows.
  • Legacy Strategies: Plan for older systems.
Domain-1.6-summary: Container runtime security focuses on protecting containers during their execution by monitoring and enforcing security policies to prevent unauthorised activities and vulnerabilities. It involves isolating containers, scanning for threats in real-time, and ensuring compliance with security standards to safeguard applications and data.
Domain-1.6-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Container Runtime Security Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define Security Baselines: Establish secure container runtime configurations.
  • Minimize Host Access: Limit container privileges on the host.
  • Secure Container Images: Scan for vulnerabilities and enforce image provenance.
  • Resource Limits: Define CPU and memory constraints for containers.
  • Network Policies: Control inter-container and external network traffic.
  • Secure Secrets Management (Containers): Avoid embedding secrets in images or environment variables.
  • Train Personnel: Educate developers and operators on container security best practices.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Container Runtime Sandboxing: Utilize technologies like seccomp, AppArmor, and SELinux.
  • Namespace Isolation: Leverage namespaces for resource and security isolation.
  • Control Group (cgroup) Limits: Enforce resource usage restrictions.
  • Immutable Containers (Where Possible): Deploy read-only container filesystems.
  • Network Segmentation (Containers): Implement network policies and microsegmentation.
  • Runtime Security Monitoring: Use tools to detect anomalous container behavior.
  • Admission Controllers: Enforce security policies at container deployment time.
  • Image Scanning and Hardening: Integrate automated vulnerability scanning and image hardening into CI/CD.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for container security.
  • Regular Audits: Verify container runtime security configurations.
  • Regular Reviews: Update security baselines and policies.
  • Measure Effectiveness: Track container-related security incidents.
  • Automated Policy Enforcement (Containers): Implement tools to automatically enforce runtime security policies.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Orchestration Platform Security (Kubernetes, etc.): Secure the container orchestration layer itself.
  • Service Mesh Security: Implement secure communication within service meshes.
  • Egress Control: Limit container access to external resources.
  • Ephemeral Containers for Debugging: Use temporary containers for troubleshooting.
Domain-1.7-summary: Service mesh security enhances the security of microservices architectures by managing, encrypting, and controlling inter-service communication through consistent, policy-driven access controls and authentication. This approach ensures that data in transit is protected and only authorised services can communicate, thereby reducing the attack surface within distributed applications.
Domain-1.7-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Service Mesh Security Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define Security Goals: Identify security requirements for service-to-service communication.
  • Establish Policy: Document authentication, authorization, and encryption policies.
  • Understand Service Identities: Clearly define and manage service identities.
  • Least Privilege (Service Communication): Allow only necessary inter-service communication.
  • Secure Control Plane: Protect the service mesh control plane components.
  • Certificate Management: Implement robust certificate issuance and rotation.
  • Train Personnel: Educate developers and operators on service mesh security concepts.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Mutual TLS (mTLS): Enforce authenticated and encrypted communication between services.
  • Authorization Policies (RBAC/ABAC): Control service access based on identity and attributes.
  • Traffic Encryption: Ensure all inter-service traffic is encrypted.
  • Secure Service Discovery: Protect the service discovery mechanism.
  • Rate Limiting and Circuit Breaking: Implement resilience and prevent abuse.
  • Audit Logging (Service Communication): Log all service-to-service interactions.
  • Policy Enforcement Points (Proxies): Securely configure sidecar proxies.
  • Integration with Identity Providers: Leverage existing identity infrastructure.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for service mesh security.
  • Regular Audits: Verify service mesh security configurations and policies.
  • Regular Reviews: Update security policies and configurations.
  • Measure Effectiveness: Track security incidents related to service communication.
  • Automated Policy Enforcement (Mesh): Implement automated enforcement of security policies within the mesh.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Control Plane Security Hardening: Secure the core service mesh components.
  • Data Plane Security Configuration: Properly configure sidecar proxies.
  • Integration with Observability Tools: Monitor service communication and security metrics.
  • Trust Domain Management: Handle trust between different service mesh deployments.
Domain-1.8-summary: Identity-based perimeter security focuses on establishing access controls and security measures based on the identity and credentials of users and devices, rather than traditional network boundaries. This model ensures that only authenticated and authorised entities can access resources, enhancing security in increasingly distributed and mobile environments.
Domain-1.8-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Identity-Based Perimeter Security Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Establish Strong Identity Management: Implement a robust IAM system.
  • Define Access Policies: Document rules based on user and device identity.
  • Centralize Identity Management: Use a directory service or identity provider.
  • Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA): Enforce MFA for all access points.
  • Device Trust/Health Checks: Verify device compliance before granting access.
  • Principle of Least Privilege (Identity): Grant minimal necessary access based on role and context.
  • Train Personnel: Educate users on secure authentication and access practices.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Identity Federation: Securely integrate with external identity providers.
  • Context-Aware Access: Enforce policies based on location, time, and device.
  • Attribute-Based Access Control (ABAC): Control access based on user and resource attributes.
  • Dynamic Authorization: Make access decisions in real-time based on context.
  • Endpoint Security: Secure devices accessing the perimeter.
  • Network Segmentation (Identity-Aware): Enforce network access based on identity.
  • Secure Remote Access (VPN with MFA): Protect remote connections with strong authentication.
  • Identity Governance: Implement processes for managing user lifecycles and access rights.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for identity and access.
  • Regular Audits: Verify identity and access controls.
  • Regular Reviews: Update access policies and user permissions.
  • Measure Effectiveness: Track unauthorized access attempts and policy violations.
  • Automated Policy Enforcement (Identity): Implement tools to automatically enforce access policies.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Zero Trust Architecture: Implement a 'never trust, always verify' model.
  • Microsegmentation (Identity-Driven): Granular control based on user and workload identity.
  • API Security (Identity-Aware): Secure API access based on authenticated and authorized identities.
  • Cloud IAM: Leverage cloud-native identity and access management services securely.

Domain-2.overview: Secure Data encompasses strategies and technologies aimed at protecting sensitive information from unauthorised access, modification, or disclosure. This involves employing encryption, access controls, and data masking techniques to safeguard data both in transit and at rest. By implementing robust security measures and adhering to compliance standards, organizations can mitigate the risks of data breaches and uphold the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of their data assets.
Domain-2.title: Secure Data
Domain-2.1-summary: Data classification involves categorizing organizational data based on sensitivity and relevance, enabling tailored protection measures and compliance with regulatory requirements. This process helps prioritise data security efforts, ensuring that higher sensitivity data receives more stringent protections to mitigate the risk of breaches and unauthorised access.
Domain-2.1-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Data Classification Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define Classification Levels: Establish clear categories for data sensitivity.
  • Develop a Data Classification Policy: Document guidelines for classifying data.
  • Identify Data Owners: Assign responsibility for data classification.
  • Establish Handling Procedures: Define security controls for each classification level.
  • Implement Data Tagging: Apply labels to data based on its classification.
  • Educate Users: Train employees on data classification policies and procedures.
  • Regularly Review and Update Policy: Ensure the policy remains relevant.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Automated Classification Tools: Utilize solutions to identify and classify data.
  • Data Loss Prevention (DLP): Enforce controls based on data classification.
  • Access Control Lists (ACLs): Implement permissions based on data classification.
  • Encryption Based on Classification: Apply stronger encryption to sensitive data.
  • Watermarking and Labeling: Visually mark classified data.
  • Monitoring and Auditing: Track access and usage of classified data.
  • Secure Storage Based on Classification: Store data according to its sensitivity level.
  • Secure Disposal Procedures: Implement secure methods for deleting classified data.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate individuals or teams responsible for data classification governance.
  • Regular Audits: Verify the accuracy and application of data classifications.
  • Regular Reviews: Update classification levels and handling procedures.
  • Measure Compliance: Track the percentage of data that is correctly classified.
  • Integrate with Data Governance Framework: Align data classification with broader governance efforts.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Cloud Data Classification: Apply classification to data stored in cloud environments.
  • Big Data Classification: Handle the challenges of classifying large and varied datasets.
  • Data Sovereignty and Regional Regulations: Consider legal and compliance requirements.
  • Integration with User Training: Reinforce data classification during security awareness training.
Domain-2.2-summary: Encryption transforms readable data into a coded format that can only be accessed or decrypted by authorised parties with the correct key, providing a critical layer of security for protecting sensitive information from unauthorised access and breaches. This technique is essential for safeguarding data at rest, in transit, and during processing across various digital platforms and communications.
Domain-2.2-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Data Encryption Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define Encryption Policy: Document standards for data encryption at rest and in transit.
  • Identify Sensitive Data: Determine data requiring encryption based on classification.
  • Key Management Strategy: Establish secure procedures for key generation, storage, and rotation.
  • Algorithm Selection: Specify approved encryption algorithms and key lengths.
  • Scope of Encryption: Define which data elements and systems require encryption.
  • Role-Based Access to Keys: Implement strict access control for encryption keys.
  • Train Personnel: Educate users on encryption policies and key handling.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Encryption at Rest: Implement encryption for stored data (databases, filesystems, backups).
  • Encryption in Transit: Enforce encryption for data during transmission (TLS/SSL).
  • End-to-End Encryption: Encrypt data from origin to destination.
  • Hardware Security Modules (HSMs): Use dedicated hardware for key management.
  • Key Rotation Automation: Automate the process of regularly changing encryption keys.
  • Secure Key Storage: Protect encryption keys from unauthorized access.
  • Application-Level Encryption: Implement encryption within applications.
  • Full Disk Encryption (FDE): Encrypt entire storage volumes on devices.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for encryption practices.
  • Regular Audits: Verify the implementation and effectiveness of encryption.
  • Regular Reviews: Update encryption policies and key management procedures.
  • Measure Effectiveness: Track the percentage of sensitive data that is encrypted.
  • Key Recovery Procedures: Establish secure methods for recovering lost keys.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Cloud Encryption: Utilize cloud-native encryption services and manage keys securely.
  • Database Encryption: Implement transparent data encryption (TDE) or other database encryption methods.
  • Email Encryption: Enforce encryption for sensitive email communications.
  • Mobile Device Encryption: Ensure encryption is enabled on mobile devices handling sensitive data.
Domain-2.3-summary: Data access control is the process of restricting access to data by defining who is authorised to view or use specific data resources, based on roles, responsibilities, or attributes. It is a fundamental security measure that helps prevent unauthorised access and data breaches, ensuring that sensitive information is only accessible to vetted individuals or systems.
Domain-2.3-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Data Access Control Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define Access Control Policy: Document rules for data access based on roles and attributes.
  • Identify Data Owners: Assign responsibility for authorizing data access.
  • Principle of Least Privilege: Grant only the necessary access to data.
  • Role-Based Access Control (RBAC): Assign access based on user roles and responsibilities.
  • Attribute-Based Access Control (ABAC): Control access based on user, resource, and environmental attributes.
  • Centralized Access Management: Manage access permissions through a central system.
  • Train Personnel: Educate users on data access policies and procedures.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Access Control Lists (ACLs): Implement file and directory permissions.
  • Database Access Controls: Manage user privileges within databases.
  • Application-Level Access Controls: Enforce access rules within applications.
  • Directory Services Integration: Leverage LDAP or Active Directory for user authentication and authorization.
  • Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA): Enforce MFA for accessing sensitive data.
  • Data Masking and Anonymization: Limit exposure of sensitive data for non-privileged users.
  • Session Management: Control and monitor user sessions.
  • Regular Access Reviews: Periodically review and revoke unnecessary access.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for data access governance.
  • Regular Audits: Verify the implementation and effectiveness of access controls.
  • Regular Reviews: Update access policies and user permissions.
  • Measure Effectiveness: Track unauthorized data access attempts and policy violations.
  • Automated Provisioning/Deprovisioning: Automate user access based on roles and lifecycle.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Cloud Data Access Control: Utilize cloud-native IAM services and access controls.
  • Big Data Access Control: Manage access to large and distributed datasets.
  • API Access Control: Secure API endpoints and data access.
  • Data Sharing Governance: Establish secure procedures for sharing data with external parties.
Domain-2.4-summary: Tokenization is the process of substituting sensitive data elements with non-sensitive equivalents, or tokens, that have no exploitable meaning or value. This method secures data by ensuring that the original information can only be retrieved through a specific mapping system, effectively protecting it during storage and transmission while reducing the risk of data breaches.
Domain-2.4-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Data Tokenization Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define Tokenization Policy: Document rules for when and how data will be tokenized.
  • Identify Data for Tokenization: Determine sensitive data elements to be protected.
  • Tokenization Method Selection: Choose appropriate tokenization techniques (e.g., format-preserving, irreversible).
  • Secure Token Vault: Implement a secure repository for mapping tokens to sensitive data.
  • Access Control for Token Vault: Restrict access to the token vault and mapping data.
  • Token Lifecycle Management: Define procedures for token generation, usage, and retirement.
  • Train Personnel: Educate users and developers on tokenization policies and usage.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Tokenization Libraries/Services: Integrate secure tokenization tools into applications.
  • Secure API for Tokenization/Detokenization: Implement protected interfaces for token operations.
  • Format-Preserving Tokenization: Maintain the format of the original data where required.
  • Cryptographic Tokenization: Use encryption techniques to generate tokens.
  • Token Vault Security Measures: Implement strong encryption and access controls for the vault.
  • Regular Token Rotation (Where Applicable): Periodically generate new tokens.
  • Auditing of Token Operations: Log all tokenization and detokenization activities.
  • Integration with Data Security Controls: Ensure tokenization works with other security measures (e.g., DLP).
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for tokenization implementation and management.
  • Regular Audits: Verify the security and effectiveness of the tokenization process.
  • Regular Reviews: Update tokenization policies and procedures based on evolving needs.
  • Measure Effectiveness: Track the reduction of sensitive data exposure through tokenization.
  • Key Management for Tokenization: Securely manage any cryptographic keys used in token generation.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • PCI DSS Compliance: Meet specific requirements for tokenizing cardholder data.
  • GDPR Compliance: Utilize tokenization to pseudonymize personal data.
  • Cloud Tokenization Services: Leverage cloud-based tokenization offerings securely.
  • Integration with Analytics: Enable analysis of tokenized data without exposing sensitive information.
Domain-2.5-summary: Data Loss Prevention (DLP) is a set of tools and processes designed to identify, monitor, and protect sensitive data to prevent unauthorised access and leaks. This approach ensures that critical information is not misused, misplaced, or accessed by unauthorised individuals, safeguarding an organization's data against loss or theft.
Domain-2.5-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Data Loss Prevention Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define DLP Policy: Document rules for preventing sensitive data loss.
  • Identify Sensitive Data: Determine data categories requiring DLP controls.
  • Data Classification Integration: Leverage data classification to inform DLP rules.
  • Define Acceptable Use: Clearly outline how sensitive data can be used and transmitted.
  • Incident Response Plan (DLP): Establish procedures for handling DLP violations.
  • Educate Users: Train employees on DLP policies and reporting procedures.
  • Regularly Review and Update Policy: Ensure DLP rules remain effective and relevant.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Endpoint DLP: Prevent data leakage from user devices.
  • Network DLP: Monitor and control data in transit across the network.
  • Cloud DLP: Extend DLP controls to cloud environments and SaaS applications.
  • Email DLP: Prevent sensitive data from being sent via email.
  • Web DLP: Control data shared through web browsers and applications.
  • Content Awareness: Implement deep content inspection to identify sensitive data.
  • Contextual Analysis: Consider user, location, and application context in DLP rules.
  • Reporting and Alerting: Generate alerts and reports on DLP policy violations.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for DLP implementation and management.
  • Regular Audits: Verify the effectiveness of DLP controls.
  • Regular Reviews: Update DLP rules and policies based on evolving threats and data landscape.
  • Tune DLP Rules: Minimize false positives and negatives.
  • Measure Effectiveness: Track the number and type of prevented data loss incidents.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Data Discovery: Implement tools to identify sensitive data across the environment.
  • User Behavior Analytics (UBA): Integrate UBA to detect risky user behavior.
  • Remediation Actions: Define automated actions to take upon DLP violations (block, quarantine, alert).
  • Integration with IR Tools: Connect DLP alerts with incident response workflows.
Domain-2.6-summary: Automated Data Security Posture Management utilises technology to continuously monitor, evaluate, and enhance the security stance of an organization's data across all environments. It automates the identification and correction of data security risks, ensuring compliance with policies and regulations, thereby minimizing the potential for data breaches and enhancing data protection efforts.
Domain-2.6-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Automated Data Posture Management Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define Data Posture Policies: Document desired security and compliance states for data.
  • Identify Key Data Elements: Determine critical data requiring continuous posture management.
  • Establish Automation Framework: Select and implement automation tools and platforms.
  • Integrate with Data Governance: Align automated posture management with overall governance.
  • Define Remediation Workflows: Establish automated responses to posture deviations.
  • Secure Automation Infrastructure: Protect the tools and scripts used for automation.
  • Train Personnel: Educate teams on data posture policies and automation tools.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Data Discovery and Classification Automation: Automatically identify and categorize data.
  • Automated Security Configuration Checks: Continuously monitor and enforce security settings.
  • Automated Compliance Monitoring: Verify adherence to regulatory requirements.
  • Policy-as-Code Implementation: Define and manage data posture policies as code.
  • Automated Vulnerability Scanning (Data-Centric): Identify vulnerabilities related to data storage and access.
  • Automated Access Control Enforcement: Automatically provision and deprovision data access.
  • Automated Encryption Enforcement: Ensure data is encrypted according to policy.
  • Automated Remediation Actions: Automatically correct misconfigurations and policy violations.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for data posture automation.
  • Regular Audits of Automation: Verify the effectiveness and accuracy of automated controls.
  • Regular Reviews of Policies and Automation Rules: Update policies and automation scripts as needed.
  • Measure Effectiveness: Track improvements in data security and compliance posture.
  • Integrate with Security Orchestration (SOAR): Coordinate data posture automation with broader security workflows.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Cloud Data Posture Management: Utilize cloud-native automation tools for data security and compliance.
  • Hybrid and Multi-Cloud Environments: Implement consistent data posture management across all environments.
  • Integration with CI/CD Pipelines: Embed data posture checks early in the development lifecycle.
  • Real-time Posture Monitoring: Continuously monitor data security and compliance status.
Domain-2.7-summary: Immutable storage is a data storage approach that prevents data from being altered or deleted after it has been written, ensuring the integrity and permanence of the stored information. This method is crucial for regulatory compliance, data protection, and ensuring the reliability of backup and archival systems, as it safeguards against data tampering and ransomware attacks.
Domain-2.7-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Immutable Storage Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define Immutability Policy: Document which data requires immutable storage and for how long.
  • Identify Critical Data: Determine data essential for recovery, compliance, or legal reasons.
  • Establish Retention Periods: Define specific retention durations for immutable data.
  • Implement Legal Hold Procedures: Outline processes for preserving data for legal or regulatory needs.
  • Access Control for Immutability Settings: Restrict who can configure or modify immutability.
  • Verification of Immutability: Implement mechanisms to confirm data cannot be altered or deleted.
  • Train Personnel: Educate teams on the purpose and usage of immutable storage.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Utilize WORM (Write Once, Read Many) Storage: Implement storage solutions with built-in immutability features.
  • Object Locking: Leverage object storage features to prevent modification or deletion.
  • Retention Policies (Storage-Level): Configure retention policies directly within the storage system.
  • Version Control with Immutability: Utilize versioning where previous versions are immutable.
  • Air-Gapped Backups (Consideration): While not strictly immutable storage, air-gapped backups offer a high degree of protection against modification.
  • Secure Deletion Prevention: Implement controls to prevent premature or unauthorized deletion of immutable data.
  • Tamper Detection Mechanisms: Employ tools to detect any unauthorized modifications.
  • Integration with Backup and Recovery: Ensure immutable storage is part of the overall data protection strategy.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for managing immutable storage.
  • Regular Audits: Verify the immutability and accessibility of protected data.
  • Regular Reviews of Policies and Retention Rules: Update policies based on evolving requirements.
  • Test Recovery Procedures: Regularly practice restoring data from immutable storage.
  • Monitor Compliance: Track adherence to retention policies and legal hold requirements.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Cloud Immutable Storage: Utilize cloud-native immutable storage services (e.g., AWS S3 Object Lock, Azure Blob Storage Immutability Policies, Google Cloud Storage Bucket Lock).
  • Compliance Requirements: Address specific regulatory requirements for data retention and immutability (e.g., SEC 17a-4).
  • Ransomware Protection: Leverage immutable storage as a key defense against ransomware attacks.
  • Long-Term Archival: Utilize immutable storage for secure and compliant long-term data archiving.
Domain-2.8-summary: Anomaly detection involves identifying patterns or activities within a data set that deviate from the expected behavior, signaling potential issues such as security breaches, fraud, or system failures. This process is essential for early threat detection and response, helping organizations to proactively address vulnerabilities and protect against malicious activities.
Domain-2.8-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Data Anomaly Detection Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define Anomaly Detection Goals: Identify the types of anomalies to detect (e.g., security, operational, compliance).
  • Identify Critical Data for Monitoring: Determine datasets where anomalies are most significant.
  • Establish Baselines of Normal Behavior: Define what constitutes typical data patterns.
  • Define Alerting Thresholds and Severity Levels: Determine when and how anomalies should trigger alerts.
  • Incident Response Plan (Anomalies): Establish procedures for investigating and responding to detected anomalies.
  • Data Governance Framework Integration: Align anomaly detection with data quality and integrity initiatives.
  • Train Personnel: Educate teams on the purpose of anomaly detection and how to interpret alerts.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Implement Anomaly Detection Tools: Utilize specialized software or integrate anomaly detection into existing systems (e.g., SIEM, data analytics platforms).
  • Statistical Anomaly Detection Techniques: Employ methods like standard deviation, z-scores, and time series analysis.
  • Machine Learning-Based Anomaly Detection: Utilize algorithms like clustering, classification, and autoencoders.
  • Behavioral Analytics: Establish user and entity behavior baselines to detect deviations.
  • Real-time Data Monitoring: Analyze data streams as they are generated.
  • Historical Data Analysis: Identify anomalies by comparing current data to historical patterns.
  • Contextual Anomaly Detection: Consider related data points and context when identifying anomalies.
  • Visualization and Reporting: Provide clear dashboards and reports of detected anomalies.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for managing anomaly detection systems.
  • Regular Tuning of Anomaly Detection Models: Optimize thresholds and algorithms to reduce false positives and negatives.
  • Regular Reviews of Anomaly Detection Rules: Update rules based on new threats, business changes, and evolving data patterns.
  • Measure Effectiveness: Track the accuracy of anomaly detection and the impact of detected anomalies.
  • Feedback Loop for Improvement: Incorporate insights from investigated anomalies to refine detection strategies.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Cloud Data Anomaly Detection: Utilize cloud-native anomaly detection services.
  • Big Data Anomaly Detection: Employ scalable techniques for large datasets.
  • Integration with Security Information and Event Management (SIEM): Correlate data anomalies with security events.
  • Operational Technology (OT) Anomaly Detection: Monitor industrial control systems for unusual behavior.

Domain-3.overview: Secure Identity involves verifying and managing the digital identities of users accessing systems, networks, and applications to prevent unauthorised access and ensure trustworthiness. It encompasses techniques such as multi-factor authentication, biometrics, and identity federation to authenticate users securely and authorise access based on their roles and permissions. By implementing robust identity management practices, organizations can reduce the risk of identity theft, fraud, and unauthorised access to sensitive information.
Domain-3.title: Secure Identity
Domain-3.1-summary: Passwords are secret character sequences used to authenticate and gain access to resources or data, serving as a fundamental aspect of digital security by verifying the identity of users. They play a critical role in protecting user accounts and sensitive information from unauthorised access, making strong, unique passwords essential for maintaining security and privacy in digital environments.
Domain-3.1-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Password Management Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define Password Policy: Document requirements for password complexity, length, and history.
  • Prohibit Password Reuse: Enforce unique passwords across all accounts.
  • Mandate Regular Password Changes: Set a reasonable password rotation schedule.
  • Discourage Common Passwords: Prohibit the use of easily guessable passwords.
  • Implement Account Lockout Policies: Limit failed login attempts.
  • Enforce Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA): Require a secondary verification method.
  • Educate Users: Train employees on password security best practices.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Password Complexity Enforcement: Utilize system settings or tools to enforce password requirements.
  • Password History Enforcement: Prevent users from reusing recent passwords.
  • Password Age Enforcement: Force users to change passwords periodically.
  • Centralized Password Management Tools: Implement password managers for users and administrators.
  • Secure Password Storage (Hashing & Salting): Ensure passwords are stored securely in databases.
  • Password Reset Mechanisms: Provide secure and user-friendly password reset options.
  • Credential Stuffing Protection: Implement measures to detect and prevent automated login attacks.
  • Integration with Identity Providers: Leverage single sign-on (SSO) where appropriate.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for password policy and management.
  • Regular Audits: Verify compliance with password policies.
  • Regular Reviews: Update password policies based on evolving threats and best practices.
  • Measure Compliance: Track password strength and adherence to policies.
  • Monitor for Breached Passwords: Utilize services to identify compromised credentials.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Administrator Password Management: Implement strong and unique passwords for administrative accounts.
  • Service Account Password Management: Securely manage passwords for non-human accounts.
  • API Key Management: Treat API keys with the same level of security as passwords.
  • BYOD Password Management: Provide guidance for secure password practices on personal devices.
Domain-3.2-summary: Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) is a method of restricting system access to authorised users based on their roles within an organization. It simplifies management and enforcement of enterprise-wide access policies by assigning permissions to roles, rather than individuals, ensuring that users have access only to the information and resources necessary for their duties, thereby enhancing security and operational efficiency.
Domain-3.2-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Role-Based Access Control Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define Roles Clearly: Identify distinct job functions and responsibilities.
  • Establish Access Policies per Role: Document the permissions associated with each role.
  • Principle of Least Privilege: Grant only the permissions necessary for a role.
  • Centralize Role Management: Manage roles and assignments through a central system.
  • Separate Duties: Assign tasks to different roles to prevent fraud and errors.
  • Regularly Review Roles and Permissions: Ensure roles remain relevant and permissions are appropriate.
  • Train Personnel: Educate users and administrators on RBAC principles and procedures.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Implement RBAC in Systems: Configure applications, databases, and infrastructure to use roles.
  • Directory Services Integration: Leverage LDAP or Active Directory for role management.
  • Group-Based Permissions: Assign permissions to groups that represent roles.
  • Automated Role Provisioning/Deprovisioning: Automatically assign and revoke roles based on user lifecycle events.
  • Role Hierarchy Implementation (Where Applicable): Define inheritance of permissions between roles.
  • Access Control Lists (ACLs) Based on Roles: Configure ACLs using role memberships.
  • Attribute-Based Access Control (ABAC) Integration (Consideration): Combine roles with attributes for finer-grained control.
  • Auditing of Role Assignments and Access: Log role assignments and access activities.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for RBAC management.
  • Regular Audits of Role Assignments: Verify that users have appropriate role assignments.
  • Regular Reviews of Role Definitions: Ensure roles align with current organizational structure and responsibilities.
  • Measure Effectiveness: Track unauthorized access attempts and policy violations related to roles.
  • Feedback Loop for Role Updates: Incorporate feedback from system administrators and users to refine roles.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Cloud RBAC: Utilize cloud-native IAM roles and policies.
  • Application RBAC: Implement role-based access control within applications.
  • Database RBAC: Manage database privileges through roles.
  • Network RBAC: Control network access based on user roles.
Domain-3.3-summary: Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) is a security mechanism that requires users to provide two or more verification factors to gain access to a resource, such as an application, online account, or a VPN. By combining something the user knows (like a password), something the user has (like a smartphone app or hardware token), and something the user is (like a fingerprint or facial recognition), MFA significantly enhances security by adding layers of defense against unauthorised access and breaches.
Domain-3.3-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Multi-Factor Authentication Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define MFA Policy: Document which systems and data require MFA.
  • Mandate MFA for All Users: Implement MFA across the organization.
  • Support Multiple MFA Methods: Offer diverse options (e.g., authenticator apps, hardware tokens, biometrics).
  • Prioritize Stronger MFA Methods: Encourage or require the use of more secure options.
  • Establish Enrollment Procedures: Provide clear guidance for users to enroll in MFA.
  • Implement Account Recovery for MFA: Define secure processes for users locked out due to MFA issues.
  • Train Personnel: Educate users on the importance and usage of MFA.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Enable MFA on All Critical Systems: Secure VPNs, email, cloud services, and internal applications.
  • Integrate with Identity Providers: Leverage IdPs for centralized MFA management.
  • Conditional Access Policies: Enforce MFA based on context (location, device, risk).
  • Step-Up Authentication: Require additional authentication for accessing sensitive resources.
  • Hardware Token Management: Implement secure processes for distributing and managing hardware tokens.
  • Authenticator App Management: Provide guidance and support for authenticator app usage.
  • Biometric Authentication Integration: Securely enable fingerprint or facial recognition where supported.
  • Monitor MFA Usage: Track enrollment rates and authentication attempts.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for MFA implementation and management.
  • Regular Audits: Verify MFA enforcement across all covered systems.
  • Regular Reviews: Update MFA policies and supported methods based on security best practices.
  • Measure Enrollment Rates: Track the percentage of users enrolled in MFA.
  • User Support for MFA Issues: Provide adequate helpdesk resources for MFA-related problems.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • BYOD Environments: Implement MFA on personal devices accessing corporate resources.
  • Service Accounts: Secure service accounts with strong, non-interactive MFA where possible.
  • Legacy Systems: Explore options for implementing MFA with older applications.
  • User Experience: Balance security with user convenience to encourage adoption.
Domain-3.4-summary: Single Sign-On (SSO) is an authentication process that allows a user to access multiple applications or systems with one set of credentials, simplifying the user experience by reducing the number of times a user needs to log in. SSO enhances both convenience and security by minimizing password fatigue and the risk of phishing, as it reduces the number of login prompts and credentials users must manage.
Domain-3.4-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Single Sign-On Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define SSO Policy: Document which applications will be integrated with SSO.
  • Centralize Identity Management: Utilize a robust Identity Provider (IdP).
  • Adopt Security Standards: Implement protocols like SAML, OAuth 2.0, and OpenID Connect.
  • Strong Authentication for IdP: Secure the IdP with MFA and strong passwords.
  • Federation Governance: Establish rules for integrating new applications.
  • Session Management Policy: Define session timeouts and revocation procedures.
  • Train Personnel: Educate users on how to use SSO and its benefits.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Implement a Central IdP: Deploy or utilize a secure and reliable Identity Provider.
  • Integrate Applications with SSO: Configure applications to authenticate against the IdP.
  • Secure Communication Channels: Use HTTPS for all communication between users, applications, and the IdP.
  • Token Management: Securely handle and store authentication tokens.
  • Session Security: Implement measures to prevent session hijacking and fixation.
  • Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) Enforcement at IdP: Secure the initial login with MFA.
  • Conditional Access Policies at IdP: Control application access based on context.
  • Monitoring and Logging of SSO Events: Track logins, access attempts, and errors.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for SSO management.
  • Regular Audits: Verify the security and functionality of the SSO infrastructure.
  • Regular Reviews: Update SSO policies and application integrations.
  • Measure Adoption Rates: Track the percentage of applications integrated with SSO.
  • Incident Response Plan (SSO): Establish procedures for handling SSO outages or security incidents.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Cloud SSO: Integrate cloud applications with the central IdP.
  • On-Premise Application Integration: Securely connect on-premise applications to SSO.
  • BYOD Access: Manage SSO access from personal devices securely.
  • Guest User Access: Implement secure SSO for external users.
Domain-3.5-summary: Privileged Access Management (PAM) is a critical security framework that controls, monitors, and manages access to an organization's critical information and resources by privileged users, such as administrators and IT personnel. PAM helps prevent security breaches by securing, auditing, and limiting the actions and reach of privileged accounts through stringent authentication methods, access controls, and user activity tracking, ensuring only authorised and authenticated users can access sensitive systems and data.
Domain-3.5-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Privileged Access Management Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Identify Privileged Accounts: Catalog all administrative, service, and emergency break-glass accounts.
  • Define PAM Policy: Document rules for privileged access, including justification and approval.
  • Principle of Least Privilege (Privileged): Grant only necessary privileges for specific tasks and durations.
  • Centralized PAM Solution: Implement a dedicated PAM tool or platform.
  • Strong Authentication for Privileged Access: Enforce MFA for all privileged accounts.
  • Regularly Review Privileged Access: Conduct periodic audits of privileged account usage and permissions.
  • Train Personnel: Educate administrators and privileged users on PAM policies and tools.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Secure Vaulting of Credentials: Store privileged account passwords and secrets in a secure, encrypted vault.
  • Just-in-Time (JIT) Access: Grant temporary privileged access only when needed.
  • Workflow-Based Access Approval: Implement approval processes for requesting and granting privileged access.
  • Session Monitoring and Recording: Monitor and record privileged user sessions.
  • Command Filtering and Control: Restrict the commands privileged users can execute.
  • Password Rotation for Privileged Accounts: Automate regular password changes for vaulted accounts.
  • Break-Glass Account Management: Securely manage and monitor the use of emergency access accounts.
  • Anomaly Detection for Privileged Sessions: Identify unusual activity within privileged sessions.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for PAM implementation and management.
  • Regular Audits of Privileged Access and Usage: Verify compliance with PAM policies and identify potential misuse.
  • Regular Reviews of PAM Policies and Controls: Update policies and configurations based on evolving threats and best practices.
  • Measure Effectiveness: Track the reduction of privileged access risks and unauthorized activity.
  • Integrate PAM with SIEM: Correlate privileged access events with other security logs for comprehensive monitoring.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Cloud PAM: Secure privileged access to cloud resources and services.
  • DevOps PAM: Manage secrets and privileged access in DevOps environments.
  • Service Account PAM: Securely manage credentials for non-human accounts.
  • Vendor PAM: Control and monitor privileged access granted to third-party vendors.
Domain-3.6-summary: Identity Federation is a system of trust that allows organizations to share identity information across multiple and diverse security domains, enabling users to access applications and services across different systems using a single set of credentials. This approach streamlines user access to a wide range of resources without the need for multiple usernames and passwords, enhancing user convenience while maintaining strict security and privacy standards through centralised authentication and authorization processes.
Domain-3.6-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Identity Federation Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define Federation Policy: Document rules and standards for federating identities with external parties.
  • Identify Federation Use Cases: Determine scenarios requiring identity federation (e.g., SaaS access, partner collaboration).
  • Establish Trust Frameworks: Define the level of trust and security requirements for federated partners.
  • Adopt Security Standards: Implement protocols like SAML, OAuth 2.0, and OpenID Connect.
  • Attribute Mapping: Define how user attributes will be exchanged with federated partners.
  • Consent Management: Implement mechanisms for user consent regarding attribute sharing.
  • Train Personnel: Educate users and administrators on identity federation processes.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Implement a Central Identity Provider (IdP): Utilize a robust IdP capable of federation.
  • Configure Trust Relationships: Establish secure connections with federated Service Providers (SPs) and other IdPs.
  • Secure Token Exchange: Ensure the secure generation, transmission, and validation of security tokens.
  • Certificate Management: Implement secure certificate handling for trust establishment.
  • Session Management (Federated): Manage user sessions across federated domains.
  • Attribute Release Control: Limit the attributes shared with federated partners.
  • Single Sign-On (SSO) Integration: Leverage SSO within the federated environment for seamless user experience.
  • Monitoring and Logging of Federation Events: Track authentication and authorization activities within the federation.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for managing identity federation.
  • Regular Audits: Verify the security and functionality of federated connections.
  • Regular Reviews of Federation Policies and Trust Frameworks: Update policies based on evolving security requirements and partner relationships.
  • Measure Adoption Rates: Track the number of applications and partners integrated via federation.
  • Incident Response Plan (Federation): Establish procedures for handling security incidents related to federated identities.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Cloud Identity Federation: Securely federate identities with cloud-based services.
  • Hybrid Identity Federation: Connect on-premises and cloud identity systems.
  • Guest User Federation: Manage access for external collaborators and partners.
  • Privacy Considerations: Adhere to privacy regulations when sharing user attributes.
Domain-3.7-summary: AI/ML anomaly detection leverages artificial intelligence and machine learning algorithms to automatically analyze data patterns and identify deviations from the norm, signaling potential issues such as fraud, security breaches, or operational disruptions. This advanced approach enables real-time detection and response to sophisticated threats, significantly enhancing the accuracy and efficiency of security operations by learning from data trends and adapting to new anomalies over time.
Domain-3.7-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving AI/ML Anomaly Detection Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define AI/ML Anomaly Detection Goals: Specify the types of anomalies to identify (security, performance, etc.) and their impact.
  • Identify Relevant Data Sources: Determine the datasets that will be used for training and detection.
  • Establish Baselines and Normal Behavior: Define what constitutes typical data patterns using AI/ML.
  • Define Alerting Strategies and Thresholds: Determine when and how AI/ML-identified anomalies should trigger alerts.
  • Incident Response Plan (AI/ML Anomalies): Establish procedures for investigating and responding to AI/ML-detected anomalies.
  • Data Governance for AI/ML: Implement policies for data quality, bias mitigation, and model explainability.
  • Train Personnel: Educate security and operations teams on how AI/ML anomaly detection works and how to interpret findings.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Select Appropriate AI/ML Models: Choose algorithms suitable for the data and anomaly types (e.g., autoencoders, clustering, time series models).
  • Data Preparation and Feature Engineering: Clean, transform, and select relevant features for model training.
  • Model Training and Evaluation: Train AI/ML models on historical data and evaluate their performance (precision, recall, F1-score).
  • Real-time Anomaly Scoring: Implement pipelines for scoring new data points against trained models.
  • Explainable AI (XAI) Implementation: Utilize techniques to understand why the AI/ML model flagged a specific anomaly.
  • Threshold Optimization: Continuously adjust alerting thresholds to minimize false positives and negatives.
  • Integration with Security and Monitoring Tools: Integrate AI/ML anomaly detection output with SIEM, logging, and alerting systems.
  • Feedback Loops for Model Improvement: Incorporate human feedback on detected anomalies to retrain and refine models.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for managing AI/ML anomaly detection systems.
  • Regular Model Monitoring and Retraining: Track model performance over time and retrain as data patterns evolve.
  • Regular Reviews of Model Configurations and Alerting Rules: Update settings based on performance and new insights.
  • Measure Effectiveness: Track the accuracy of AI/ML anomaly detection and its impact on incident detection and prevention.
  • Bias Detection and Mitigation: Implement processes to identify and mitigate bias in training data and models.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Cloud-Based AI/ML Services: Leverage cloud-native AI/ML platforms for scalability and ease of deployment.
  • Edge AI/ML for Anomaly Detection: Deploy models at the network edge for real-time analysis of local data.
  • Handling Concept Drift: Implement strategies to address changes in the underlying data distribution over time.
  • Collaboration Between Data Science and Security/Operations Teams: Foster communication and shared understanding.
Domain-3.8-summary: Contextual or Risk-Based Access Control (RBAC) is a dynamic approach to managing user access that evaluates the risk associated with each access request based on the context of the situation. Factors such as user location, device security status, time of access, and the sensitivity of the accessed data are considered to adjust authentication requirements and access permissions in real-time. This method enhances security by adapting protections based on the assessed risk level of a transaction or access attempt, ensuring stricter controls are applied in higher-risk scenarios.
Domain-3.8-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Contextual / Risk Based Access Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define Risk Scoring Framework: Establish criteria and weights for assessing access risk (user, device, environment, resource).
  • Develop Contextual Access Policies: Document rules that consider various contextual factors before granting access.
  • Identify Critical Resources: Determine high-value assets requiring stringent access controls.
  • Integrate with Identity Management: Leverage user attributes and roles in risk calculations.
  • Define Step-Up Authentication Triggers: Determine conditions that require stronger authentication.
  • Establish Continuous Risk Assessment: Implement mechanisms for ongoing evaluation of access risk.
  • Train Personnel: Educate users and administrators on contextual access policies and risk scoring.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Implement a Contextual Access Engine: Utilize a dedicated solution or integrate capabilities into IAM systems.
  • Gather Contextual Data: Integrate with systems providing user location, device health, time of access, etc.
  • Real-time Risk Calculation: Dynamically assess access risk at the time of the request.
  • Policy Enforcement Points (PEPs): Implement controls at access gateways and application layers.
  • Step-Up Authentication Mechanisms: Trigger MFA or stronger authentication based on risk score.
  • Adaptive Access Controls: Adjust access privileges dynamically based on changing risk levels.
  • User and Entity Behavior Analytics (UEBA) Integration: Incorporate behavioral data into risk assessments.
  • Logging and Monitoring of Access Decisions: Track contextual factors and risk scores associated with access attempts.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for managing contextual access policies and risk scoring.
  • Regular Audits of Access Decisions: Verify the appropriateness of risk-based access controls.
  • Regular Reviews of Risk Scoring Framework and Policies: Update criteria and rules based on evolving threats and business needs.
  • Measure Effectiveness: Track the reduction of unauthorized access and the impact of risk-based controls.
  • Feedback Loop for Policy Refinement: Incorporate insights from access logs and security incidents to improve policies.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Cloud Contextual Access: Utilize cloud-native conditional access and risk-based authentication features.
  • Zero Trust Implementation: Contextual access is a key component of a Zero Trust architecture.
  • API Access Control: Apply contextual and risk-based controls to API access.
  • Mobile and Remote Access: Implement strong contextual controls for users accessing resources remotely or on mobile devices.

Domain-4.overview: Secure Applications refer to software programs and systems that are developed and maintained with a focus on mitigating security risks and vulnerabilities. This involves implementing secure coding practices, regular security assessments, and patch management to prevent exploitation by malicious actors. By prioritizing security throughout the software development lifecycle, organizations can ensure that their applications resist attacks and protect sensitive data from unauthorised access or manipulation.
Domain-4.title: Secure Application
Domain-4.1-summary: Application dependency management involves the process of identifying, tracking, and controlling the libraries and components an application relies on to function properly. This includes ensuring compatibility between different versions of dependencies, managing updates to mitigate security vulnerabilities, and minimizing conflicts that can arise from incompatible or outdated components. Effective dependency management is crucial for maintaining the stability, security, and reliability of software applications, as it helps developers to manage the complexities associated with integrating external software components.
Domain-4.1-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Application Dependency Management Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define Dependency Management Policy: Document standards for identifying, tracking, and managing application dependencies.
  • Inventory Application Dependencies: Create a comprehensive list of all direct and transitive dependencies for each application.
  • Establish Approval Processes for Dependencies: Define procedures for approving the use of new dependencies.
  • Define Vulnerability Management for Dependencies: Outline how known vulnerabilities in dependencies will be addressed.
  • License Compliance Management: Establish processes for tracking and managing the licenses of used dependencies.
  • Train Personnel: Educate developers and security teams on dependency management best practices.
  • Regularly Review and Update Policy: Ensure the dependency management policy remains relevant and effective.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Software Composition Analysis (SCA) Tools: Implement SCA tools to automatically identify and analyze dependencies.
  • Dependency Scanning in CI/CD Pipelines: Integrate SCA tools into development pipelines to identify vulnerabilities early.
  • Dependency Version Pinning: Specify exact versions of dependencies to ensure consistent builds and reduce risk.
  • Dependency Update Management: Establish a process for regularly updating dependencies to address security vulnerabilities and bugs.
  • Vulnerability Database Integration: Ensure SCA tools are integrated with up-to-date vulnerability databases.
  • License Compliance Scanning: Utilize SCA tools to identify and manage dependency licenses.
  • Bill of Materials (SBOM) Generation: Automatically generate SBOMs for applications.
  • Automated Remediation (Where Possible): Implement automation to update or patch vulnerable dependencies.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for application dependency management.
  • Regular Audits of Application Dependencies: Verify the accuracy of dependency inventories and the status of vulnerabilities.
  • Regular Reviews of Approved Dependencies: Ensure that used dependencies remain necessary and secure.
  • Measure Effectiveness: Track the number of identified and remediated dependency vulnerabilities.
  • Establish Metrics for License Compliance: Monitor and report on adherence to dependency licenses.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Open Source Software (OSS) Management: Implement specific controls for managing the risks associated with OSS dependencies.
  • Third-Party Library Management: Extend dependency management practices to external libraries and components.
  • Containerized Applications: Scan container images for vulnerable dependencies.
  • Microservices Architectures: Manage dependencies across a distributed set of services.
Domain-4.2-summary: Static Application Security Testing (SAST) is a type of security testing that analyzes source code, bytecode, or binary code for vulnerabilities that could lead to security breaches, without executing the application. It identifies issues such as input validation errors, insecure dependencies, and potential backdoors early in the software development lifecycle, allowing developers to address vulnerabilities before deployment. SAST is an essential component of secure coding practices, helping to ensure that applications are built with security in mind from the ground up.
Domain-4.2-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Static Application Security Testing Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define SAST Policy: Document when and how SAST will be performed in the SDLC.
  • Identify Critical Applications: Prioritize applications for SAST based on risk.
  • Integrate SAST into SDLC: Implement SAST early and often (Shift Left).
  • Establish Remediation Guidelines: Define how identified vulnerabilities will be addressed.
  • Triage and Prioritization Process: Outline how SAST findings will be reviewed and prioritized.
  • Educate Developers: Train developers on common vulnerabilities and SAST findings.
  • Regularly Review and Update Policy: Ensure the SAST policy remains relevant and effective.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Select Appropriate SAST Tools: Choose tools that support relevant languages and frameworks.
  • Configure SAST Tools Effectively: Customize rulesets and configurations for accuracy.
  • Automate SAST Scans: Integrate SAST into CI/CD pipelines for automated execution.
  • Centralized SAST Results Management: Utilize platforms for managing and tracking SAST findings.
  • IDE Integration: Enable developers to run SAST scans within their development environment.
  • Incremental Scanning: Focus scans on changed code for faster feedback.
  • False Positive Reduction: Implement strategies for minimizing and managing false positives.
  • Developer Feedback Mechanisms: Provide clear and actionable feedback to developers on SAST findings.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for SAST implementation and management.
  • Regular Audits of SAST Implementation: Verify that SAST is being performed as intended.
  • Regular Reviews of SAST Findings and Remediation Efforts: Track the progress of vulnerability remediation.
  • Measure Effectiveness: Track the number and severity of vulnerabilities identified and fixed through SAST.
  • Tool and Rule Updates: Regularly update SAST tools and rulesets to cover new vulnerabilities.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Infrastructure-as-Code (IaC) SAST: Extend SAST to scan infrastructure configurations.
  • Configuration-as-Code SAST: Analyze configuration files for security weaknesses.
  • Mobile Application SAST: Utilize tools specific for mobile application code analysis.
  • Web Application SAST: Focus SAST efforts on web application codebases.
Domain-4.3-summary: Secure coding practices involve adopting standards and guidelines to write software code that is resistant to vulnerabilities and attacks. These practices encompass validating input, sanitizing output, managing errors securely, implementing proper authentication and authorization checks, and encrypting sensitive data. By integrating security into the development process from the beginning, secure coding practices help prevent common security flaws, ensuring that software is robust against unauthorised access and exploitation, thereby protecting both the applications and the data they process.
Domain-4.3-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Secure Code Practices Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define Secure Coding Standards: Document coding guidelines to prevent common vulnerabilities.
  • Adopt Secure Development Lifecycle (SDLC): Integrate security throughout the development process.
  • Mandate Security Training for Developers: Educate developers on secure coding principles and common threats.
  • Establish Code Review Processes: Implement peer reviews with a security focus.
  • Promote Threat Modeling: Identify potential security threats during the design phase.
  • Utilize Secure Libraries and Frameworks: Encourage the use of well-vetted and secure components.
  • Regularly Review and Update Standards: Ensure coding guidelines remain relevant and address emerging threats.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Static Application Security Testing (SAST) Integration: Automate static code analysis.
  • Dynamic Application Security Testing (DAST) Integration: Perform runtime security testing.
  • Interactive Application Security Testing (IAST) Integration: Combine static and dynamic analysis.
  • Code Linters with Security Rules: Utilize linters configured to identify security flaws.
  • Input Validation and Sanitization: Implement robust input handling to prevent injection attacks.
  • Secure Output Encoding: Protect against cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerabilities.
  • Error Handling and Logging: Implement secure error handling and logging practices.
  • Secure Session Management: Protect user sessions from hijacking.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for promoting and enforcing secure coding practices.
  • Regular Audits of Code Reviews: Verify that security considerations are addressed during reviews.
  • Track and Remediate Security Vulnerabilities: Monitor the identification and fixing of code-related flaws.
  • Measure Effectiveness: Track the reduction of security vulnerabilities introduced in code.
  • Foster a Security-Conscious Development Culture: Encourage developers to prioritize security.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Language-Specific Secure Practices: Tailor coding standards to the specific programming languages used.
  • Framework-Specific Security Considerations: Understand and address security features and limitations of used frameworks.
  • Cloud-Native Development Security: Apply secure coding principles in cloud environments.
  • Mobile Application Secure Development: Address unique security challenges in mobile app development.
Domain-4.4-summary: Dynamic Application Security Testing (DAST) is a security testing methodology that assesses an application from the outside in, by testing it in its running state. This approach is used to identify vulnerabilities that an attacker could exploit, such as issues related to the execution environment or runtime issues that can't be detected through static analysis. DAST tools simulate attacks on a web application to find security weaknesses and are effective in identifying runtime problems, such as authentication and authorization issues, session management problems, and vulnerabilities to cross-site scripting (XSS) or SQL injection attacks.
Domain-4.4-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Dynamic Application Security Testing Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define DAST Policy: Document when and how DAST will be performed in the SDLC and in production.
  • Identify Critical Applications and Endpoints: Prioritize applications and specific URLs/APIs for DAST based on risk.
  • Integrate DAST into SDLC: Implement DAST regularly, ideally after deployment to test environments.
  • Establish Remediation Guidelines: Define how identified vulnerabilities will be addressed.
  • Triage and Prioritization Process: Outline how DAST findings will be reviewed and prioritized.
  • Educate Testers and Developers: Train teams on common web vulnerabilities and DAST findings.
  • Regularly Review and Update Policy: Ensure the DAST policy remains relevant and effective.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Select Appropriate DAST Tools: Choose tools that support relevant web technologies and testing types (e.g., OWASP Top 10).
