  • Configure DAST Tools Effectively: Customize scan profiles and authentication settings for thorough testing.
  • Automate DAST Scans: Integrate DAST into CI/CD pipelines or schedule regular scans in test and production-like environments.
  • Centralized DAST Results Management: Utilize platforms for managing and tracking DAST findings.
  • Authentication and Session Handling: Properly configure DAST tools to handle application authentication and session management.
  • API Testing Capabilities: Ensure DAST tools can effectively test REST and other APIs.
  • False Positive Management: Implement strategies for identifying and managing false positives.
  • Developer Feedback Mechanisms: Provide clear and actionable feedback to developers on DAST findings, including request/response details.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for DAST implementation and management.
  • Regular Audits of DAST Implementation: Verify that DAST is being performed as intended and on the correct targets.
  • Regular Reviews of DAST Findings and Remediation Efforts: Track the progress of vulnerability remediation identified through DAST.
  • Measure Effectiveness: Track the number and severity of vulnerabilities identified and fixed through DAST.
  • Tool and Rule Updates: Regularly update DAST tools and scan configurations to cover new vulnerabilities and attack vectors.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Web Application DAST: Focus DAST efforts on web applications and their components.
  • API DAST: Specifically test API endpoints for security vulnerabilities.
  • Cloud Application DAST: Configure DAST tools to test applications deployed in cloud environments.
  • Production DAST (Carefully Managed): Implement controlled DAST scans in production environments with appropriate safeguards and monitoring.
Domain-4.5-summary: A Web Application Firewall (WAF) is a security solution that monitors, filters, and blocks HTTP/S traffic to and from a web application to protect against malicious attempts to compromise the system or exfiltrate data. By applying a set of rules to web traffic, WAF can prevent common web vulnerabilities such as SQL injection, cross-site scripting (XSS), and file inclusion attacks, among others. It acts as a shield between the web application and the internet, providing a critical layer of security for web applications by inspecting incoming traffic for malicious patterns and blocking potential threats.
Domain-4.5-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Web Application Firewall Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define WAF Policy: Document rulesets, deployment architecture, and operational procedures.
  • Identify Protected Applications: Determine which web applications and APIs require WAF protection.
  • Understand Application Traffic: Analyze normal and malicious traffic patterns.
  • Establish WAF Rulesets: Implement rules to address common web vulnerabilities (e.g., OWASP Top 10).
  • Define False Positive Handling: Establish procedures for identifying and addressing legitimate blocked traffic.
  • Implement Change Management for WAF Rules: Control modifications to WAF configurations.
  • Train Personnel: Educate security and operations teams on WAF configuration and management.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Deploy WAF Correctly: Choose appropriate deployment mode (e.g., reverse proxy, inline, cloud-native).
  • Configure Rulesets Accurately: Tailor rules to the specific needs of protected applications.
  • Enable Logging and Monitoring: Collect and analyze WAF logs for security events.
  • Implement Virtual Patching: Deploy WAF rules to address vulnerabilities before code fixes are deployed.
  • Rate Limiting and DDoS Protection: Configure WAF to mitigate denial-of-service attacks.
  • Bot Management: Implement rules to identify and manage malicious bots.
  • SSL/TLS Inspection: Enable WAF to inspect encrypted traffic.
  • Regularly Update WAF Rules: Keep rulesets current with the latest threat intelligence.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for WAF management.
  • Regular Audits of WAF Configuration: Verify that WAF rules are correctly implemented and effective.
  • Regular Reviews of WAF Logs and Performance: Analyze logs for security incidents and optimize WAF performance.
  • Measure Effectiveness: Track the number and type of attacks blocked by the WAF.
  • Testing of WAF Rules: Regularly test WAF rules against known attack vectors.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Cloud WAF: Utilize cloud-native WAF services for cloud-based applications.
  • API Security with WAF: Configure WAF to protect APIs from common attacks.
  • Custom Rule Development: Create specific WAF rules to address unique application vulnerabilities.
  • Integration with SIEM: Forward WAF logs to a SIEM for centralized security monitoring and correlation.
Domain-4.6-summary: Container scanning is a security practice that involves examining container images for vulnerabilities, misconfigurations, and security best practices violations before they are deployed to production. This process helps identify and remediate security issues early in the development cycle, reducing the risk of deploying containers with known vulnerabilities. Container scanning tools analyze the contents of container images, including the base image, added packages, and the application itself, to provide insights into potential security weaknesses and compliance with security policies, thereby ensuring that containers are secure and ready for deployment.
Domain-4.6-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Container Scanning Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define Container Scanning Policy: Document when and how container images will be scanned in the SDLC.
  • Identify Critical Images and Registries: Prioritize scanning for images used in production and trusted registries.
  • Integrate Scanning into SDLC: Implement scanning early and often (Shift Left), ideally before deployment.
  • Establish Remediation Guidelines: Define how identified vulnerabilities will be addressed in container images.
  • Triage and Prioritization Process: Outline how scanning findings will be reviewed and prioritized.
  • Educate Developers and Operators: Train teams on container security risks and scanning results.
  • Regularly Review and Update Policy: Ensure the container scanning policy remains relevant and effective.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Select Appropriate Container Scanning Tools: Choose tools that integrate with registries and CI/CD pipelines.
  • Configure Scanning Tools Effectively: Customize scan policies to match organizational requirements.
  • Automate Scanning in CI/CD Pipelines: Integrate scanning to automatically check images during build and deployment.
  • Centralized Scanning Results Management: Utilize platforms for managing and tracking container scan findings.
  • Registry Integration: Configure scanners to automatically scan images in container registries.
  • Layered Scanning: Analyze each layer of the container image for vulnerabilities.
  • False Positive Reduction: Implement strategies for minimizing and managing false positives.
  • Developer Feedback Mechanisms: Provide clear and actionable feedback to developers on container vulnerabilities.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for container scanning implementation and management.
  • Regular Audits of Scanning Implementation: Verify that scanning is being performed as intended and on all relevant images.
  • Regular Reviews of Scanning Findings and Remediation Efforts: Track the progress of vulnerability remediation in container images.
  • Measure Effectiveness: Track the number and severity of vulnerabilities identified and fixed through container scanning.
  • Tool and Policy Updates: Regularly update scanning tools and policies to cover new vulnerabilities and best practices.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Base Image Security: Harden base images and regularly update them.
  • Application Dependency Scanning within Containers: Ensure vulnerabilities in application dependencies within containers are also addressed.
  • Configuration Scanning within Containers: Analyze container configurations for security weaknesses.
  • Runtime Scanning (Consideration): Explore runtime security tools that monitor container behavior for anomalies.
Domain-4.7-summary: Runtime Application Self-Protection (RASP) is a security technology that integrates with an application or its runtime environment to detect and prevent attacks in real time. RASP does this by continuously monitoring the application's behavior and the context of that behavior. When it identifies potentially malicious activities, it can take immediate action to mitigate the threat. This can include terminating a session, alerting administrators, or even modifying the application's response to prevent exploitation. RASP offers an added layer of protection by working from within the application, providing detailed insight into its data flow and logic, and enabling precise defense mechanisms against attacks without requiring changes to the application's code.
Domain-4.7-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Runtime Application Self-Protection Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define RASP Policy: Document which applications will be protected by RASP and the desired protection levels.
  • Identify Critical Applications: Prioritize applications for RASP deployment based on risk and sensitivity.
  • Understand Application Architecture: Analyze the application's runtime environment and potential attack vectors.
  • Establish Response Actions: Define how RASP will react to detected attacks (block, log, alert).
  • False Positive Handling: Establish procedures for identifying and tuning RASP to minimize false positives.
  • Implement Change Management for RASP Rules: Control modifications to RASP configurations.
  • Train Personnel: Educate security and development teams on RASP functionality and alerts.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Select Appropriate RASP Solution: Choose a solution compatible with the application's runtime environment and language.
  • Deploy RASP Agents Correctly: Ensure proper installation and configuration of RASP agents within the application.
  • Configure Protection Modules: Enable relevant RASP modules to address specific attack types (e.g., SQL injection, XSS, command injection).
  • Fine-Tune Rulesets: Customize RASP rules to the specific behavior and needs of the application.
  • Implement Centralized Management: Utilize a console for managing RASP policies and monitoring events across applications.
  • Enable Logging and Monitoring: Collect and analyze RASP logs for security events and potential attacks.
  • Integrate with WAF (Consideration): Understand how RASP complements or overlaps with WAF functionality.
  • Regularly Update RASP Agents and Rules: Keep the RASP solution current with the latest threat intelligence and patches.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for RASP implementation and management.
  • Regular Audits of RASP Configuration: Verify that RASP is correctly deployed and configured according to policy.
  • Regular Reviews of RASP Logs and Performance: Analyze RASP logs for blocked attacks and optimize performance.
  • Measure Effectiveness: Track the number and type of attacks blocked by RASP and the reduction in application vulnerabilities exploited at runtime.
  • Testing of RASP Rules: Regularly test RASP rules against known attack vectors in a staging environment.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Cloud-Native RASP: Utilize RASP solutions designed for cloud-based applications and containerized environments.
  • Microservices Architectures: Deploy and manage RASP across distributed microservices.
  • Performance Impact Assessment: Carefully monitor the performance overhead introduced by RASP agents.
  • Integration with SIEM: Forward RASP logs to a SIEM for centralized security monitoring and correlation with other security events.
Domain-4.8-summary: Interactive Application Security Testing (IAST) is a security testing approach that combines elements of both static application security testing (SAST) and dynamic application security testing (DAST) to detect vulnerabilities in applications. IAST tools are designed to be integrated into the application runtime environment, where they can observe and analyze application behavior and data flow in real-time as the application interacts with users or automated tests. This method allows for the detection of security issues that are only evident during the application's execution, such as runtime injection attacks or authentication problems. By providing immediate feedback to developers, IAST facilitates the rapid identification and remediation of security vulnerabilities within the software development lifecycle, enhancing the application's overall security posture.
Domain-4.8-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Interactive Application Security Testing Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define IAST Policy: Document when and how IAST will be integrated into the SDLC.
  • Identify Critical Applications and Features: Prioritize applications and specific functionalities for IAST.
  • Integrate IAST into SDLC: Implement IAST during testing phases, ideally alongside QA and functional testing.
  • Establish Remediation Guidelines: Define how identified vulnerabilities will be addressed.
  • Triage and Prioritization Process: Outline how IAST findings will be reviewed and prioritized.
  • Educate Testers and Developers: Train teams on how IAST works and how to interpret its findings.
  • Regularly Review and Update Policy: Ensure the IAST policy remains relevant and effective.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Select Appropriate IAST Solution: Choose a solution compatible with the application's language, frameworks, and testing environment.
  • Deploy IAST Agents Correctly: Ensure proper installation and configuration of IAST sensors within the application.
  • Automate IAST Scans: Integrate IAST into automated testing suites (e.g., Selenium, JUnit).
  • Centralized IAST Results Management: Utilize platforms for managing and tracking IAST findings.
  • Configure Coverage Settings: Ensure IAST tools are configured to monitor a broad range of application behavior.
  • Correlate Static and Dynamic Findings: Leverage IAST's ability to link code-level insights with runtime behavior.
  • False Positive Reduction and Tuning: Implement strategies for minimizing and managing false positives.
  • Developer Feedback Mechanisms: Provide clear and actionable feedback to developers on IAST findings, including code location and runtime context.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for IAST implementation and management.
  • Regular Audits of IAST Implementation: Verify that IAST is being used effectively in the testing process.
  • Regular Reviews of IAST Findings and Remediation Efforts: Track the progress of vulnerability remediation identified through IAST.
  • Measure Effectiveness: Track the number and severity of vulnerabilities identified and fixed through IAST.
  • Tool and Agent Updates: Regularly update IAST tools and agents to ensure coverage of new vulnerabilities and technologies.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Integration with Bug Tracking Systems: Automatically create tickets for IAST findings.
  • Performance Impact Assessment: Monitor the performance overhead introduced by IAST agents in testing environments.
  • Cloud Application IAST: Utilize IAST solutions designed for cloud-based applications.
  • Microservices Architectures: Deploy and manage IAST agents across distributed microservices.

Domain-5.overview: Secure Network involves implementing measures to protect networks and data transmission from unauthorised access, interception, or tampering. This includes deploying firewalls, intrusion detection systems, and virtual private networks (VPNs) to safeguard communication channels and prevent external threats. By enforcing encryption protocols, segmenting networks, and regularly updating security configurations, organizations can maintain the integrity and confidentiality of their network infrastructure.
Domain-5.title: Secure Network
Domain-5.1-summary: Network firewalls act as a barrier to control access between trusted and untrusted networks, using predefined rules to block or allow traffic. Network segmentation divides a network into smaller, isolated segments to limit the spread of threats and enforce specific security policies, enhancing overall security and reducing the attack surface.
Domain-5.1-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Firewalls & Segmentation Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define Segmentation Policy: Document network zones, trust levels, and traffic flow rules.
  • Establish Firewall Policy: Define rules for inbound, outbound, and inter-zone traffic.
  • Identify Critical Assets and Data Flows: Understand the network paths of sensitive information.
  • Principle of Least Privilege (Network): Allow only necessary network communication between segments.
  • Document Network Architecture: Maintain up-to-date network diagrams showing segmentation.
  • Implement Change Management for Firewall Rules: Control modifications to firewall configurations.
  • Train Personnel: Educate security and network teams on segmentation policies and firewall management.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Deploy Firewalls at Zone Boundaries: Implement firewalls to enforce segmentation policies.
  • Utilize VLANs and Subnets: Implement logical network separation.
  • Implement Microsegmentation: Enforce granular control at the workload level.
  • Configure Access Control Lists (ACLs): Define specific traffic rules on network devices.
  • Implement Next-Generation Firewall (NGFW) Features: Leverage application awareness, intrusion prevention, and threat intelligence.
  • Secure Routing Protocols: Implement secure routing configurations.
  • Regular Rulebase Optimization: Remove unused or overly permissive firewall rules.
  • Centralized Firewall Management: Utilize platforms for managing firewall policies across multiple devices.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for firewall and segmentation management.
  • Regular Audits of Firewall Rules and Segmentation: Verify compliance with policies and identify potential weaknesses.
  • Regular Reviews of Network Architecture and Policies: Update segmentation and firewall strategies based on evolving threats and business needs.
  • Measure Effectiveness: Track blocked traffic, security incidents related to network access, and adherence to segmentation policies.
  • Regular Penetration Testing of Network Controls: Validate the effectiveness of firewall rules and segmentation.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Cloud Network Security: Utilize cloud-native firewall and segmentation services (Security Groups, Network ACLs, PrivateLink).
  • Hybrid Cloud Segmentation: Implement consistent segmentation across on-premises and cloud environments.
  • Container Network Security: Secure communication between containers using network policies.
  • OT/ICS Network Segmentation: Isolate operational technology networks from enterprise IT.
Domain-5.2-summary: Secure network protocols, such as HTTPS, SSL/TLS, and SSH, are designed to encrypt data in transit, ensuring confidentiality, integrity, and authentication between communicating devices. These protocols protect sensitive information from eavesdropping, tampering, and impersonation attacks, making them essential for secure communications over untrusted networks like the internet.
Domain-5.2-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Secure Data Protocols Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define Secure Protocol Policy: Document approved protocols for data transmission and storage.
  • Identify Sensitive Data Transmission Channels: Determine where secure protocols are mandatory.
  • Prioritize End-to-End Security: Favor protocols that encrypt data throughout its lifecycle.
  • Disable Insecure Protocols: Identify and disable outdated or vulnerable protocols (e.g., SSLv3, TLS 1.0/1.1).
  • Implement Strong Cryptographic Standards: Specify approved cipher suites and key lengths.
  • Certificate Management Policy: Establish procedures for obtaining, managing, and renewing digital certificates.
  • Train Personnel: Educate developers and system administrators on secure data protocol usage.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Enforce TLS/SSL for Web Traffic (HTTPS): Configure web servers to use strong TLS versions and cipher suites.
  • Implement Secure Shell (SSH): Use SSH for secure remote administration and file transfer.
  • Utilize Secure File Transfer Protocol (SFTP): Replace insecure FTP with SFTP.
  • Encrypt Email Communication (TLS, S/MIME, PGP): Implement email encryption where sensitive data is transmitted.
  • Secure Database Connections: Configure applications to use encrypted connections to databases.
  • Implement Secure APIs (HTTPS, API Keys, OAuth 2.0): Protect API endpoints with appropriate security mechanisms.
  • Encrypt Data at Rest (AES-256 or equivalent): Secure stored data with strong encryption algorithms.
  • Virtual Private Networks (VPNs) with Strong Protocols (IPsec, OpenVPN): Use secure VPN protocols for remote access.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for managing secure data protocols.
  • Regular Audits of Protocol Configurations: Verify that systems are using approved secure protocols and configurations.
  • Regular Reviews of Protocol Policies and Standards: Update policies based on emerging threats and best practices.
  • Vulnerability Scanning for Protocol Weaknesses: Regularly scan systems for vulnerabilities related to insecure protocols.
  • Certificate Monitoring and Management: Track certificate expiration and ensure timely renewals.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Cloud Services Security: Utilize secure protocols offered by cloud providers (e.g., AWS KMS, Azure Key Vault).
  • IoT Device Security: Implement secure communication protocols for IoT devices.
  • Mobile Application Security: Ensure secure data transmission within mobile applications.
  • Legacy System Modernization: Plan for the replacement of systems using insecure protocols.
Domain-5.3-summary: Access Control Lists (ACLs) are a set of rules that control the access to network resources, specifying which users or system processes are granted access to objects, as well as what operations are allowed on given objects. They play a crucial role in defining permissions and enhancing security by explicitly allowing or denying traffic flow to and from specific addresses, ports, or protocols within a network.
Domain-5.3-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Access Control Lists Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define ACL Policy: Document standards for creating, managing, and auditing ACLs.
  • Identify Resources Requiring ACLs: Determine which files, directories, network segments, and other objects need access controls.
  • Principle of Least Privilege (ACLs): Grant only the necessary permissions to users or groups.
  • Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) Integration: Manage ACLs primarily through roles rather than individual users.
  • Centralized ACL Management: Utilize tools or systems for consistent ACL application.
  • Regularly Review ACLs: Ensure ACLs remain appropriate and up-to-date.
  • Train Personnel: Educate administrators on ACL concepts and management.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Implement ACLs on File Systems: Configure permissions for files and directories.
  • Implement Network ACLs (NACLs): Control traffic at the subnet level.
  • Implement Security Groups (Cloud): Manage access to cloud resources.
  • Apply ACLs to Databases: Control access to database objects.
  • Utilize Group-Based ACL Management: Assign permissions to groups representing roles.
  • Automate ACL Deployment (IaC): Manage ACLs through infrastructure-as-code.
  • Regularly Audit Effective Permissions: Verify the actual permissions granted to users.
  • Enforce Standardized ACL Configurations: Utilize templates or baselines for consistency.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for ACL management.
  • Regular Audits of ACL Configurations: Verify adherence to ACL policies.
  • Regular Reviews of ACL Policies: Update policies based on evolving security needs.
  • Measure Effectiveness: Track unauthorized access attempts blocked by ACLs.
  • Automated ACL Provisioning/Deprovisioning: Manage ACLs as part of user lifecycle management.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Cloud ACL Management: Utilize cloud-native ACL services effectively.
  • Hybrid Environment ACL Consistency: Ensure consistent ACL application across on-premises and cloud.
  • Granular ACL Control: Implement fine-grained permissions where necessary.
  • ACL Inheritance Management: Understand and manage how permissions are inherited.
Domain-5.4-summary: Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) and Intrusion Prevention Systems (IPS) are critical components of network security that monitor network traffic to detect and respond to malicious activities. IDS systems analyze traffic for signs of attacks and generate alerts, whereas IPS systems actively block detected threats in real time, preventing potential damage to the network infrastructure.
Domain-5.4-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Intrusion Detection and Prevention Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define IDS/IPS Policy: Document deployment strategy, rule management, and incident response procedures.
  • Identify Critical Network Segments and Assets: Determine key areas requiring monitoring and protection.
  • Establish Baseline Network Traffic: Understand normal network behavior to identify anomalies.
  • Define Alerting Thresholds and Severity Levels: Determine when and how alerts should be triggered and prioritized.
  • Integrate with Incident Response Plan: Outline how IDS/IPS alerts will be handled.
  • Regularly Review and Update Policy: Ensure the IDS/IPS policy remains relevant and effective.
  • Train Personnel: Educate security and network teams on IDS/IPS functionality and alert handling.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Strategic Deployment of Sensors: Place IDS/IPS sensors at critical network ingress/egress points and within segments.
  • Proper Configuration of Rulesets: Tailor rules to the specific threats and vulnerabilities relevant to the environment.
  • Enable Comprehensive Logging: Capture detailed information about detected events.
  • Real-time Monitoring and Alerting: Implement systems for continuous analysis and immediate notifications.
  • Signature-Based Detection: Utilize regularly updated signature databases for known threats.
  • Anomaly-Based Detection: Employ behavioral analysis to identify suspicious deviations from baselines.
  • Traffic Normalization and Deobfuscation: Enhance detection capabilities against evasive techniques.
  • Automated Blocking (IPS): Configure IPS to automatically block malicious traffic based on defined rules.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for IDS/IPS management.
  • Regular Tuning of Rules and Thresholds: Minimize false positives and negatives.
  • Regular Reviews of Logs and Alerts: Analyze detected events to identify trends and improve rules.
  • Measure Effectiveness: Track the number and type of intrusions detected and prevented.
  • Regular Testing of IDS/IPS Capabilities: Simulate attacks to validate detection and prevention effectiveness.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Cloud IDS/IPS: Utilize cloud-native security services for threat detection and prevention in cloud environments.
  • Network Segmentation Integration: Align IDS/IPS deployment with network segmentation strategy.
  • Encrypted Traffic Inspection (Carefully Managed): Implement SSL/TLS decryption for inspection where necessary and with appropriate controls.
  • Integration with Threat Intelligence Feeds: Utilize external threat intelligence to enhance detection capabilities.
Domain-5.5-summary: Traffic analysis involves the systematic examination of data packets flowing through a network to identify patterns, detect anomalies, and understand behavior. This process is essential for optimizing network performance, ensuring security by identifying potential threats, and aiding in troubleshooting by pinpointing sources of problems within network traffic.
Domain-5.5-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Network Traffic Analysis Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define NTA Policy: Document scope of analysis, data retention, and usage guidelines.
  • Identify Critical Network Segments and Assets: Determine key areas for traffic monitoring.
  • Establish Baseline Network Behavior: Understand normal traffic patterns for anomaly detection.
  • Define Alerting Criteria and Thresholds: Determine when and how suspicious traffic should trigger alerts.
  • Integrate with Incident Response Plan: Outline how NTA findings will be used in investigations.
  • Regularly Review and Update Policy: Ensure the NTA policy remains relevant and effective.
  • Train Personnel: Educate security and network teams on NTA tools and analysis techniques.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Strategic Deployment of Packet Capture Devices (TAPs/SPANs): Place sensors at key network points to collect traffic.
  • Implement Network Flow Monitoring (NetFlow, sFlow, IPFIX): Collect metadata about network traffic.
  • Utilize NTA Tools: Deploy specialized software for real-time and historical traffic analysis.
  • Deep Packet Inspection (DPI) (Carefully Managed): Analyze packet content for malicious payloads and anomalies.
  • Behavioral Analysis: Identify deviations from established network baselines.
  • Anomaly Detection Algorithms: Employ statistical and machine learning techniques to detect unusual traffic patterns.
  • Integration with Threat Intelligence Feeds: Correlate traffic patterns with known malicious IPs and domains.
  • Visualization and Reporting: Provide dashboards and reports for understanding network traffic and identifying threats.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for NTA implementation and management.
  • Regular Tuning of Analysis Rules and Thresholds: Minimize false positives and negatives.
  • Regular Reviews of NTA Findings: Analyze detected events to identify trends and improve analysis techniques.
  • Measure Effectiveness: Track the number and type of threats identified through NTA.
  • Data Retention Management: Securely store and manage captured network data according to policy.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Cloud Network Traffic Analysis: Utilize cloud-native network monitoring and analysis tools.
  • Encrypted Traffic Analysis: Explore techniques like metadata analysis and TLS fingerprinting.
  • Integration with SIEM and SOAR: Correlate NTA findings with other security events and automate responses.
  • OT/ICS Network Traffic Analysis: Monitor industrial control system network traffic for anomalies and threats.
Domain-5.6-summary: Secure connections refer to communication channels established between two endpoints, such as devices or servers, that are protected against eavesdropping, tampering, and unauthorised access. These connections typically use cryptographic protocols like SSL/TLS to encrypt data in transit, ensuring confidentiality, integrity, and authentication of the transmitted information, thereby safeguarding sensitive data from interception or manipulation by malicious actors.
Domain-5.6-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Secure Data Connections Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define Secure Connection Policy: Document approved protocols, encryption standards, and authentication methods.
  • Identify Sensitive Data Transmission Paths: Determine all points where sensitive data is exchanged.
  • Prioritize End-to-End Encryption: Favor protocols that secure data from source to destination.
  • Enforce Strong Authentication: Implement robust authentication mechanisms for all data connections.
  • Certificate Management Policy: Establish procedures for managing digital certificates used for secure connections.
  • Disable Insecure Protocols and Configurations: Identify and eliminate weak protocols and settings.
  • Train Personnel: Educate developers and administrators on establishing and maintaining secure data connections.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Enforce TLS/SSL for Web and API Traffic (HTTPS): Configure servers and clients for secure web communication.
  • Implement Secure Shell (SSH): Use SSH for secure remote access and data transfer.
  • Utilize Secure File Transfer Protocol (SFTP): Replace insecure FTP for file sharing.
  • Encrypt Database Connections: Configure applications to use encrypted connections to database servers.
  • Secure Messaging Protocols (TLS, MTLS): Implement encryption and authentication for messaging services.
  • Virtual Private Networks (VPNs) with Strong Protocols (IPsec, OpenVPN): Secure remote network access.
  • API Security Measures (TLS, API Keys, OAuth 2.0, mTLS): Protect API endpoints with appropriate authentication and authorization.
  • Regularly Update Libraries and Frameworks: Ensure underlying security components are patched against known vulnerabilities.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for managing secure data connections.
  • Regular Audits of Connection Configurations: Verify that secure protocols and settings are correctly implemented.
  • Regular Reviews of Policies and Standards: Update policies based on evolving threats and best practices.
  • Vulnerability Scanning for Connection Weaknesses: Identify systems with insecurely configured data connections.
  • Certificate Monitoring and Management: Track certificate expiration and ensure timely renewals.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Cloud Service Connections: Securely connect to and between cloud services using their recommended protocols.
  • Microservices Communication (mTLS): Implement mutual TLS for secure service-to-service communication.
  • IoT Device Communication: Secure data transmission from and to IoT devices.
  • Legacy System Security: Implement compensating controls for systems that cannot fully support modern secure protocols.
Domain-5.7-summary: Microsegmentation is a network security strategy that involves dividing a network into smaller, isolated segments to enhance security by enforcing stricter access controls and policies between individual workloads or applications. By implementing fine-grained segmentation, organizations can limit lateral movement of threats, reduce the attack surface, and minimise the impact of breaches by containing them within isolated segments, thereby improving overall security posture.
Domain-5.7-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Network Microsegmentation Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define Microsegmentation Policy: Document the strategy for granular network segmentation at the workload level.
  • Identify Critical Applications and Data Flows: Understand interdependencies and communication paths between workloads.
  • Establish Security Zones at Workload Level: Define fine-grained security boundaries based on application tiers, functions, or sensitivity.
  • Principle of Least Privilege (Workload Communication): Allow only necessary network communication between specific workloads.
  • Document Microsegmentation Architecture: Maintain detailed diagrams of workload communication rules.
  • Implement Change Management for Microsegmentation Rules: Control modifications to microsegmentation policies.
  • Train Personnel: Educate security, network, and application teams on microsegmentation concepts and tools.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Software-Defined Networking (SDN): Leverage SDN for dynamic and policy-driven microsegmentation.
  • Next-Generation Firewalls (NGFWs) with Granular Control: Utilize NGFWs capable of enforcing workload-level policies.
  • Microsegmentation Platforms: Implement dedicated microsegmentation solutions.
  • Network Segmentation Overlays: Employ overlay networks to create isolated workload segments.
  • Host-Based Firewalls: Configure firewalls on individual servers or containers to control local traffic.
  • Service Mesh Policies: Implement network policies within a service mesh for containerized applications.
  • Zero Trust Network Access (ZTNA): Extend Zero Trust principles to internal workload communication.
  • Regular Testing of Microsegmentation Rules: Validate the effectiveness of implemented policies.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for microsegmentation implementation and management.
  • Regular Audits of Microsegmentation Rules: Verify compliance with policies and identify potential weaknesses.
  • Regular Reviews of Application Dependencies and Traffic Flows: Update microsegmentation policies based on changes.
  • Measure Effectiveness: Track the reduction of lateral movement risk and the containment of security incidents.
  • Automated Policy Enforcement: Implement tools to automatically enforce microsegmentation rules.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Cloud Microsegmentation: Utilize cloud-native network security controls for granular workload isolation.
  • Container Microsegmentation: Secure communication between containers and pods within orchestration platforms.
  • Hybrid Cloud Microsegmentation: Implement consistent policies across on-premises and cloud environments.
  • Integration with Security Monitoring: Correlate microsegmentation events with other security logs for comprehensive visibility.
Domain-5.8-summary: Zero Trust Network Access (ZTNA) is a security model that assumes no trust for any user or device inside or outside the corporate network perimeter. Instead of relying on traditional network perimeters, ZTNA verifies every user and device attempting to connect to resources, regardless of their location, before granting access based on policies and contextual factors. This approach minimises the risk of unauthorised access and lateral movement of threats, providing a more robust and adaptive security posture in today's dynamic and distributed IT environments.
Domain-5.8-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Zero Trust Network Access Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define Zero Trust Principles: Embrace 'never trust, always verify' for all access attempts.
  • Identify Protected Resources: Determine the critical applications, data, and services requiring ZTNA.
  • Establish Identity as the Control Plane: Leverage strong identity and authentication for access decisions.
  • Implement Microsegmentation: Isolate resources to limit the blast radius of breaches.
  • Enforce Least Privilege Access: Grant only the minimum necessary access based on context.
  • Assume Breach: Design security controls with the understanding that breaches can occur.
  • Train Personnel: Educate users and administrators on ZTNA principles and access workflows.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Implement a ZTNA Solution: Deploy a dedicated ZTNA platform or leverage integrated capabilities.
  • Strong Identity and Authentication: Enforce MFA and strong password policies.
  • Device Trust and Health Checks: Verify device compliance before granting access.
  • Contextual Access Policies: Grant access based on user identity, device posture, location, time, and other factors.
  • Microsegmentation Enforcement: Implement granular network segmentation at the application or workload level.
  • Policy Enforcement Points (PEPs): Deploy gateways or proxies to enforce ZTNA policies.
  • Continuous Monitoring and Validation: Constantly verify user and device trust throughout the session.
  • Secure Remote Access: Replace traditional VPNs with ZTNA for more secure remote connectivity.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for ZTNA implementation and management.
  • Regular Audits of ZTNA Policies and Access Decisions: Verify the effectiveness of implemented controls.
  • Regular Reviews of Risk Scoring Framework and Contextual Factors: Update policies based on evolving threats and business needs.
  • Measure Effectiveness: Track the reduction of lateral movement and unauthorized access.
  • Integration with Security Information and Event Management (SIEM): Correlate ZTNA logs with other security events.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Cloud ZTNA: Utilize cloud-native ZTNA solutions for cloud-based resources.
  • Hybrid Environment ZTNA: Implement consistent ZTNA policies across on-premises and cloud environments.
  • Workload-to-Workload ZTNA: Secure communication between applications and services.
  • User-to-Application ZTNA: Secure access for both internal and external users to applications.

Domain-6.overview: Secure Recovery refers to the process of restoring a system to a functional state after a disruption or compromise while ensuring the integrity and security of the recovered environment. It involves creating backups of critical data, implementing recovery procedures, and validating the authenticity of recovery components to prevent further damage or exploitation. By following secure recovery practices, organizations can minimise downtime, mitigate risks, and maintain trust in their systems' resilience against potential threats.
Domain-6.title: Secure Recovery
Domain-6.1-summary: Backups and redundancy are essential components of data protection and disaster recovery strategies, ensuring the availability, integrity, and resilience of critical data and systems. Backups involve creating copies of data and storing them in separate locations to mitigate the risk of data loss due to hardware failures, human errors, or cyberattacks. Redundancy, on the other hand, involves deploying duplicate hardware, networks, or services to provide failover capabilities and maintain continuous operation in the event of component failures or disruptions. Together, backups and redundancy help organizations minimise downtime, recover quickly from disasters, and maintain business continuity.
Domain-6.1-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Backup & Redundancy Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define Backup Policy: Document scope, frequency, retention, and recovery procedures.
  • Identify Critical Data and Systems: Prioritize assets for backup and redundancy based on business impact.
  • Establish Recovery Time Objectives (RTOs) and Recovery Point Objectives (RPOs): Define acceptable downtime and data loss limits.
  • Implement Redundancy for Critical Components: Design systems with failover capabilities.
  • Secure Backup Storage: Protect backup data from unauthorized access and ransomware.
  • Regularly Test Backup and Recovery Procedures: Validate the ability to restore data and failover systems.
  • Train Personnel: Educate IT staff on backup and recovery procedures.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Implement Automated Backup Solutions: Utilize tools for scheduled and consistent backups.
  • Follow the 3-2-1 Backup Rule: Maintain at least three copies of data, on two different media, with one offsite.
  • Utilize Incremental and Differential Backups: Optimize backup storage and time.
  • Implement Replication for Redundancy: Replicate critical data and systems to secondary locations.
  • Implement Failover Mechanisms: Configure automatic or manual failover for redundant systems.
  • Secure Offsite Backups: Store backups in a physically separate and secure location.
  • Regularly Verify Backup Integrity: Ensure backups are restorable and not corrupted.
  • Monitor Backup and Replication Jobs: Track the success and status of backup and redundancy processes.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for backup and redundancy management.
  • Regular Audits of Backup and Redundancy Configurations: Verify adherence to policies and best practices.
  • Regular Reviews of RTOs and RPOs: Update objectives based on business needs.
  • Document Recovery Procedures in Detail: Create step-by-step guides for restoring data and failing over systems.
  • Conduct Disaster Recovery Drills: Simulate outages to test recovery capabilities and team preparedness.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Cloud Backup and Recovery: Utilize cloud-native backup and disaster recovery services.
  • Hybrid Cloud Backup and DR: Implement strategies for protecting data and systems across on-premises and cloud environments.
  • Database Backup and Recovery: Implement specific procedures for critical databases.
  • Application-Level Backups: Ensure application-specific data and configurations are backed up.
Domain-6.2-summary: A Disaster Recovery Plan (DRP) is a documented set of procedures and strategies designed to recover and restore IT infrastructure, systems, and data in the event of a disaster or disruptive incident. It outlines the steps to be taken before, during, and after a disaster to minimise downtime, mitigate risks, and ensure business continuity. DRPs typically include measures such as data backups, redundancy, failover mechanisms, and recovery processes tailored to specific scenarios, ensuring organizations can respond effectively to disruptions and resume critical operations with minimal impact.
Domain-6.2-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Disaster Recovery Planning Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define DRP Policy: Document scope, objectives, roles, responsibilities, and procedures for disaster recovery.
  • Business Impact Analysis (BIA): Identify critical business processes and their dependencies on IT systems.
  • Risk Assessment for Disasters: Evaluate potential threats and their likelihood and impact.
  • Establish Recovery Time Objectives (RTOs) and Recovery Point Objectives (RPOs): Define acceptable downtime and data loss for critical processes.
  • Develop Recovery Strategies: Outline specific approaches for restoring IT services (e.g., failover, restoration from backup).
  • Communication Plan: Define procedures for internal and external communication during a disaster.
  • Train Personnel: Educate relevant teams on their roles and responsibilities in the DRP.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Implement Redundancy and Failover Mechanisms: Configure systems to automatically or manually fail over to secondary sites.
  • Establish Offsite Recovery Location: Secure a secondary site for disaster recovery.
  • Implement Data Replication: Continuously or periodically replicate critical data to the recovery site.
  • Automated Recovery Processes: Utilize tools to automate the failover and recovery of systems and applications.
  • Secure Backup and Restore Procedures: Ensure backups are protected and can be reliably restored at the recovery site.
  • Network Recovery Plan: Outline steps for restoring network connectivity at the recovery site.
  • Application Recovery Plan: Detail procedures for recovering critical applications and their data.
  • Regularly Test the DRP (Disaster Recovery Drills): Simulate disaster scenarios to validate the plan's effectiveness.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate a responsible team or individual for DRP development and maintenance.
  • Regular Reviews of the DRP: Update the plan based on changes in IT infrastructure, business processes, and threat landscape.
  • Document Recovery Procedures in Detail: Create step-by-step guides for all recovery tasks.
  • Track RTO and RPO Compliance: Monitor the ability to meet defined recovery objectives during tests.
  • Lessons Learned from Drills: Incorporate findings from disaster recovery tests to improve the plan.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Cloud-Based DR: Leverage cloud services for disaster recovery (e.g., AWS DRS, Azure Site Recovery, Google Cloud DR).
  • Hybrid Cloud DR: Plan for disaster recovery involving both on-premises and cloud environments.
  • Business Continuity Planning (BCP) Integration: Align the DRP with the broader business continuity plan.
  • Legal and Regulatory Compliance: Ensure the DRP meets relevant legal and industry requirements.
Domain-6.3-summary: Consistent versioning is a practice of systematically managing and documenting changes to software, files, or documents by assigning unique identifiers or labels to each iteration or release. This enables users to track and reference specific versions, ensuring clarity, accuracy, and accountability throughout the development or revision process. Consistent versioning facilitates collaboration, rollback capabilities, and the ability to compare different versions, fostering efficient development, maintenance, and quality assurance practices.
Domain-6.3-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Consistent Software Versioning Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define Versioning Scheme: Adopt a clear and consistent versioning standard (e.g., Semantic Versioning).
  • Document Versioning Policy: Outline how version numbers will be assigned for different types of changes.
  • Establish Branching Strategy: Implement a clear branching model in version control (e.g., Gitflow).
  • Tag Releases Consistently: Use tags in version control to mark stable releases.
  • Automate Versioning (Where Possible): Integrate versioning into build processes.
  • Communicate Versioning to Stakeholders: Ensure teams understand the versioning scheme.
  • Train Personnel: Educate developers and release managers on the versioning policy and tools.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Utilize Version Control Systems (VCS): Implement Git, SVN, or a similar system.
  • Enforce Tagging Conventions: Establish rules for creating and naming release tags.
  • Automate Build Number Generation: Include build numbers in addition to semantic versions.
  • Integrate Versioning with Package Management: Ensure consistent versioning of libraries and dependencies.
  • Document API Versioning: Implement and communicate versioning for APIs.
  • Use Versioning in Deployment Pipelines: Track and manage deployments based on software versions.
  • Maintain Release Notes: Document changes associated with each release.
  • Support Older Versions (as needed): Define a policy for supporting previous software versions.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for managing software versioning.
  • Regular Audits of Versioning Practices: Verify adherence to the defined versioning scheme.
  • Regular Reviews of Versioning Policy: Update the policy based on team needs and industry best practices.
  • Measure Consistency: Track adherence to tagging conventions and release processes.
  • Automate Version Bumping (Consideration): Explore tools to automatically increment version numbers based on commit history.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Monorepo vs. Polyrepo Versioning: Adapt versioning strategy based on repository structure.
  • Semantic Versioning for Libraries: Strictly adhere to SemVer for reusable components.
  • Long-Term Support (LTS) Releases: Define and manage LTS versions with extended support periods.
  • Mobile Application Versioning: Follow platform-specific versioning guidelines (e.g., iOS build and version).
Domain-6.4-summary: Automated failovers are mechanisms implemented in IT systems to automatically redirect traffic or workload from a failed or impaired component to a healthy one without manual intervention. This ensures continuous operation and minimises downtime by swiftly responding to hardware failures, network disruptions, or other system faults. Automated failovers rely on predefined triggers, monitoring systems, and orchestrated processes to swiftly detect and mitigate issues, thereby maintaining service availability and enhancing overall resilience and reliability of the system.
Domain-6.4-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Automated Failovers Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define Failover Policy: Document which systems require automated failover and the conditions for triggering it.
  • Identify Critical Systems and Services: Prioritize systems based on RTO and business impact.
  • Establish Failover Criteria: Define specific metrics and thresholds that initiate automated failover.
  • Design for Redundancy: Ensure critical systems have redundant components or instances.
  • Automated Failback Planning: Define procedures for automatically returning to the primary system.
  • Testing and Validation Policy: Outline the frequency and scope of automated failover testing.
  • Train Personnel: Educate operations teams on automated failover mechanisms and monitoring.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Implement Clustering Technologies: Utilize clustering for application and database high availability.
  • Load Balancers with Health Checks: Configure load balancers to detect failures and redirect traffic.
  • Replication Technologies: Implement synchronous or asynchronous replication for data consistency.
  • Automated Failover Scripts and Orchestration: Develop scripts or use orchestration tools to automate the failover process.
  • DNS Failover Mechanisms: Configure DNS to automatically point to secondary resources upon failure.
  • Storage Replication and Failover: Implement storage-level replication for data availability.
  • Monitoring and Alerting: Implement comprehensive monitoring to detect failure conditions.
  • Automated Failback Procedures: Configure systems to automatically revert to the primary instance when it recovers.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for managing automated failover configurations.
  • Regular Testing of Automated Failovers: Simulate failure scenarios to validate the effectiveness of automated mechanisms.
  • Regular Reviews of Failover Policies and Criteria: Update policies based on system changes and lessons learned from testing.
  • Measure Effectiveness: Track failover times, success rates, and impact on service availability.
  • Automated Logging and Analysis of Failover Events: Monitor and analyze failover occurrences to identify areas for improvement.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Cloud-Native Failover Services: Utilize auto-scaling groups, availability zones, and region failover capabilities.
  • Hybrid Cloud Failover: Plan and automate failover between on-premises and cloud environments.
  • Application-Aware Failover: Implement failover mechanisms that understand the state and dependencies of applications.
  • Database Failover Automation: Configure automatic failover for critical database systems.
Domain-6.5-summary: Identity lifecycle management is the process of managing the entire lifecycle of user identities within an organization, from creation to retirement. It involves various stages such as provisioning, deprovisioning, authentication, authorization, and maintenance of user accounts and permissions. Identity lifecycle management ensures that users have appropriate access to resources based on their roles and responsibilities, while also addressing security, compliance, and efficiency requirements throughout the user's tenure within the organization.
Domain-6.5-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Software Lifecycle Management Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define SDLC Methodology: Adopt a structured approach (e.g., Agile, Waterfall) with defined phases.
  • Establish Governance Framework: Outline roles, responsibilities, and decision-making processes.
  • Implement Requirements Management: Define processes for capturing, documenting, and managing requirements.
  • Define Change Management Process: Control modifications to software throughout its lifecycle.
  • Establish Release Management Procedures: Define how software is built, tested, and deployed.
  • Implement Security Throughout the SDLC (Shift Left): Integrate security practices into each phase.
  • Train Personnel: Educate all stakeholders on the SDLC methodology and their roles.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Version Control Systems (VCS): Utilize Git or similar for code management and tracking.
  • Continuous Integration/Continuous Delivery (CI/CD) Pipelines: Automate build, test, and deployment processes.
  • Automated Testing Frameworks: Implement unit, integration, and end-to-end testing.
  • Issue Tracking Systems: Use Jira or similar for managing bugs and tasks.
  • Artifact Repositories: Utilize Nexus or Artifactory for storing and managing build artifacts.
  • Configuration Management Tools: Manage infrastructure and application configurations as code.
  • Monitoring and Logging: Implement systems for application and infrastructure monitoring.
  • Automated Security Testing Tools (SAST, DAST, IAST): Integrate security testing into the CI/CD pipeline.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for each phase of the SDLC.
  • Regular Reviews and Audits: Assess adherence to SDLC processes and policies.
  • Performance Metrics Tracking: Monitor key metrics like cycle time, defect rates, and deployment frequency.
  • Retrospectives and Lessons Learned: Regularly review past projects and processes for improvement.
  • Process Automation: Identify opportunities to automate manual tasks within the SDLC.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Agile vs. Waterfall Adaptation: Tailor the SDLC to the specific needs of projects and teams.
  • Open Source Software Management: Implement policies for using and contributing to OSS.
  • Third-Party Component Management: Control the use and updates of external libraries and frameworks.
  • Legacy System Management: Define strategies for maintaining and modernizing older software.
Domain-6.6-summary: Storage scanning refers to the process of systematically inspecting data storage systems, such as disks, file servers, or cloud repositories, to identify and mitigate security risks, vulnerabilities, or malicious activities. This includes scanning for malware, unauthorised access, data leaks, or other anomalies that may compromise the integrity, confidentiality, or availability of stored data. Storage scanning tools employ various techniques such as signature-based detection, behavioral analysis, and heuristic algorithms to proactively identify and remediate potential threats, ensuring the security and compliance of data storage environments.
Domain-6.6-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Storage Scanning & Monitoring Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define Storage Scanning Policy: Document the scope, frequency, and types of storage scans.
  • Identify Critical Storage Assets: Determine key storage systems and data repositories.
  • Establish Monitoring Requirements: Define what storage metrics and events should be tracked.
  • Define Alerting Thresholds and Severity Levels: Determine when and how storage-related alerts should be triggered.
  • Integrate with Incident Response Plan: Outline how storage-related alerts and findings will be handled.
  • Data Classification Integration: Leverage data classification to prioritize scanning and monitoring efforts.
  • Train Personnel: Educate storage administrators and security teams on scanning and monitoring tools and procedures.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Implement Vulnerability Scanning for Storage Systems: Regularly scan storage infrastructure for known security weaknesses.
  • Malware Scanning on Storage: Implement solutions to scan stored files for malicious software.
  • Configuration Compliance Scanning: Verify storage system configurations against security baselines.
  • Capacity Monitoring: Track storage utilization and forecast future needs.
  • Performance Monitoring: Monitor storage IOPS, latency, and throughput.
  • Access Control Monitoring: Track access attempts and permissions on storage resources.
  • Anomaly Detection for Storage Activity: Identify unusual patterns in storage access or usage.
  • Centralized Logging and Monitoring: Aggregate storage logs and metrics in a central platform.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for storage scanning and monitoring.
  • Regular Audits of Scanning and Monitoring Configurations: Verify that tools are correctly configured and policies are followed.
  • Regular Reviews of Alerts and Findings: Analyze detected events to identify trends and improve rules.
  • Measure Effectiveness: Track the number and type of storage-related vulnerabilities and incidents detected.
  • Automated Remediation (Where Possible): Implement automation to address common storage misconfigurations or issues.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Cloud Storage Scanning and Monitoring: Utilize cloud-native security and monitoring services for storage.
  • Object Storage Scanning: Implement scanning solutions for object storage services.
  • Database Security Scanning and Monitoring: Utilize tools specific to database security.
  • Network Attached Storage (NAS) Scanning and Monitoring: Implement solutions for NAS devices.
Domain-6.7-summary: Advanced key management involves the sophisticated handling and protection of cryptographic keys used to secure sensitive data and communications. This includes the generation, storage, distribution, rotation, and destruction of encryption keys in a manner that maximises security and minimises risks. Advanced key management solutions often incorporate features such as key lifecycle management, secure key storage, role-based access controls, key rotation policies, and integration with hardware security modules (HSMs) or cloud-based key management services. These measures ensure that cryptographic keys are properly managed and safeguarded throughout their lifecycle, maintaining the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of encrypted data.
Domain-6.7-recommendation:
Recommendations for Improving Advanced Key Management Maturity

I. Foundational Practices & Policy
  • Define Key Management Policy: Document comprehensive procedures for the entire key lifecycle.
  • Centralized Key Management System (KMS): Implement a dedicated platform for managing cryptographic keys.
  • Strong Key Generation Practices: Utilize cryptographically secure random number generators.
  • Secure Key Storage: Employ Hardware Security Modules (HSMs) or equivalent secure storage.
  • Strict Access Control for Keys: Implement granular RBAC and separation of duties.
  • Key Lifecycle Management: Define procedures for key creation, distribution, usage, rotation, archiving, and destruction.
  • Train Personnel: Educate administrators and developers on advanced key management concepts and tools.
II. Technical Controls & Implementation
  • Hardware Security Modules (HSMs): Utilize HSMs for secure key generation, storage, and cryptographic operations.
  • Key Wrapping: Encrypt keys with other keys for secure storage and transport.
  • Split Knowledge and Dual Control: Require multiple authorized individuals for sensitive key operations.
  • Automated Key Rotation: Implement scheduled and event-triggered key rotation.
  • Secure Key Injection and Retrieval: Establish secure methods for key loading and access.
  • Auditing and Logging of Key Operations: Maintain a comprehensive audit trail of all key management activities.
  • Cryptographic Agility: Design systems to easily support different algorithms and key lengths.
  • Integration with Applications and Services: Securely integrate KMS with applications requiring encryption.
III. Governance & Continuous Improvement
  • Assign Ownership: Designate responsible teams/individuals for key management governance.
  • Regular Audits of Key Management Practices: Verify adherence to policies and identify potential vulnerabilities.
  • Regular Reviews of Key Lifecycle Procedures: Update procedures based on evolving threats and best practices.
  • Measure Effectiveness: Track key usage, rotation frequency, and compliance with policies.
  • Disaster Recovery for Keys: Implement secure backup and recovery procedures for encryption keys.
IV. Specific Considerations
  • Cloud KMS: Utilize cloud-native key management services and understand their security models.
  • Bring Your Own Key (BYOK) / Hold Your Own Key (HYOK): Implement strategies for managing your own keys in the cloud.
  • Federated Key Management: Manage keys across different environments or organizations.
  • Post-Quantum Cryptography Readiness: Monitor and plan for the transition to post-quantum algorithms.
